editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE PLATONICK LADY. A Comedy. As it is Acted at the QUEENS THEATRE IN THE HAY-MARKET.
By the Author of the Gameſter, and Love's Contrivance.

LONDON, Printed for James Knapton, at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-Yard, and Egbert Sanger, at the Poſt-Houſe at the Middle-Temple-Gate in Fleetſtreet. 1707. Price 1s. 6d. Where may be had all Sorts of PLAYS.

div.head: To all the Generous Encouragers of Female Ingenuity, this Play is Humbly Dedicated.
div.p: MY Muſe choſe to make this Univerſal Addreſs, hoping, among the numerous Crowd, to find ſome Souls Great enough to protect her againſt the Carping Malice of the Vulgar World; who think it a proof of their Senſe, to diſlike every thing that is writ by Women. I was the more induc'd to this General Application, from the Uſage I have met on all ſides.

A Play ſecretly introduc'd to the Houſe, whilſt the Author remains unknown, is approv'd by every Body: The Actors cry it up, and are in expectation of a great Run; the Bookſeller of a Second Edition, and the Scribler of a Sixth Night: But if by chance the Plot's diſcover'd, and the Brat found Fatherleſs, immediately it flags in the Opinion of thoſe that extoll'd it before, and the Bookſeller falls in his Price, with this Reaſon only, It is a Woman's. Thus they alter their Judgment, by the Eſteem they have for the Author, tho' the Play is ſtill the ſame. They ne'er reflect, that we have had ſome Male-Productions of this kind, void of Plot and Wit, and full as inſipid as ever a Woman's of us all.

I can't forbear inſerting a Story which my Bookſeller, that printed my Gameſter, told me, of a Spark that had ſeen my Gameſter three or four times, and lik'd it extremely: Having bought one of the Books, ask'd who the Author was; and being told, a Woman, threw down the Book, and put up his Money, ſaying, he had ſpent too much after it already, and was ſure if the Town had known that, it wou'd never have run ten days. No doubt this was a Wit in his own Eyes. It is ſuch as theſe that rob us of that which inſpires the Poet, Praiſe. And it is ſuch as theſe made him that Printed my Comedy call'd, Love's Contrivance; or, Medin
cin Malgre lui, put two Letters of a wrong Name to it; which tho' it was the height of Injuſtice to me, yet his impoſing on the Town turn'd to account with him; and thus paſſing for a Man's, it has been play'd at leaſt a hundred times.

And why this Wrath againſt the Womens Works? Perhaps you'll anſwer, becauſe they meddle with things out of their Sphere: But I ſay, no; for ſince the Poet is born, why not a Woman as well as a Man? Not that I wou'd derogate from thoſe great Men who have a Genius, and Learning to improve that Genius: I only object againſt thoſe ill-natur'd Criticks, who wanting both, think they have a ſufficient claim to Senſe, by railing at what they don't underſtand. Some have arm'd themſelves with reſolution not to like the Play they paid to ſee; and if in ſpite of Spleen they have been pleas'd againſt their Will, have maliciouſly reported it was none of mine, but given me by ſome Gentleman: Nay, even my own Sex, which ſhou'd aſſert our Prerogative againſt ſuch Detractors, are often backward to encourage a Female Pen.

Wou'd theſe profeſt Enemies but conſider what Examples we have had of Women that excell'd in all Arts; in Muſick, Painting, Poetry; alſo in War: Nay, to our immortal Praiſe, what Empreſſes and Queens have fill'd the World? What cannot England boaſt from Women? The mighty Romans felt the Power of Boadicea's Arm; Eliza made Spain tremble; but ANN, the greateſt of the Three, has ſhook the Man that aim'd at Univerſal Sway. After naming this Miracle, the Glory of our Sex, ſure none will ſpitefully cavil at the following Scenes, purely becauſe a Woman writ'em. This I dare venture to ſay in their behalf, there is a Plot and Story in them, I hope will entertain the Reader; which is the utmoſt Ambition of,

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: REjoice, ye Fair, the Britiſh Warrior's come,
Victorious o're, to your ſoft Wars at home.
Each Conqueror flies, with eager Longing's fraught,
To claſp the Darling Fair, for which he fought.
He lays his Trophies down before thoſe Eyes,
By which Inſpir'd, he won the Glorious Prize.
Prouder, when wellcom'd by his Generous Fair,
Of dying in her Arms, than Conquering there.
O! cou'd our Bards of Britains Iſle but write
With the ſame Fire with which our Hero's fight:
Or cou'd our Stage but repreſent a Scene,
To Copy that on great Ramillis Plain;
Then we with Courage wou'd aſſert our Plays,
And to your glorious Laurels joyn our Bays.
But our poor Pegaſus, a Beaſt of eaſe,
Cares not for foraging beyond the Seas:
Content with London Provender, he flyes,
To make each Coxcomb he can find, a Prize:
And after trudging long, perhaps he may
Pick up a Set of Fools, to furniſh out a Play.
To make him Eat, and you to Entertain.
That for his ſafety fought beyond the Main.
Your Courage There, but Here your Mercy ſhow;
The Brave ſcorn to inſult a Proſtrate Poe.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: TO you, the Tyrant Criticks of the Age,
To you, who make ſuch Havock on the Stage;
Aſſault with Fury every coming Scene,
Like Hero's arm'd at Ramellis, or Turin.
Whilſt vanquiſh'd Wit, ſhrunk from her Native-Glory,
Like the Cow'd Gaul, too weakly ſtands before Ye.
Since then the Poets play this Looſing Game,
I, a poor Suppliant in the Muſes Name,
Beg to avert our trembling Author's Fate;
And, like the ſad Bavarian Advocate,
Reſiſtance Vain, we to your Mercy fly.
And court you now to lay your Thunder by.
Of Slaughter'd Wits, let the Effuſion ceaſe,
We, like the Humble Lewis, ſue for Peace.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: Deſign'd to be Spoken by Mrs. Bracegirdle, but came too late.
Wittten by the Author of Tunbridge-Walks.

lg.l: WHat mighty pains our Scribling Sot has ſhown,
To Ridicule our Sex, and Praiſe his own.
As if we Women muſter'd all our Charms,
To tempt an odious Fellow to our Arms.
One Lady proves ſo fond, or rather mad,
She'd fain confeſs a Child ſhe never had.
Alas! how many Nymphs about this Town,
Have pretty Moppits, that they dare not own?
Then a Weſt-country Dam'sel trots to Town,
And talks of Paint, Falſe-hair, and Rumpt-up-Gown,
Things which to Men ſhou'd never be reveal'd,
But equally with Cuckoldom conceal'd.
Yet, tell me, Sirs, don't you as nice appear,
With your falſe Calves, Bardaſh, and Fav'rites here?
Nay, in Side-Boxes too, I've often known,
'Mongſt Flaxen-Wiggs, Complexions not their own;
Who hiſs good Plays, and to Camilla fly,
Draw out their Pocket-glaſſes, Squint, and Cry,
[Sings.] Theſe Eyes are made ſo killing, &c.
Young Templers too, with upſtart forward Graces,
When Pummis-ſtone has travell'd o're their Faces,
March hither, where Mobb'd Hoods too often ply,
And want a Lodging, tho' Six-ſtories high;
Where the fond Youth the modeſt Dame implores,
And at Day-break ejects her out of Doors.
Some Cheapſide-Bobbs too trudge it to our Play,
Faith, Jack, this Hay-Market's a curſed way:
What ſignifie the Quality or Wits,
The Money, Daniel, riſes from us Cits.
Who, like Cock-Sparrows, hop about the Benches,
And court, with Six-pences, fat Orange-Wenches.
In ſhort, you Men have more Fantaſtick ways,
More Follies, than can e're be ſtuft in Plays:
But ſince all Satyr's for your Mirth deſign'd,
Excuſe the Errors, which to Night you find,
And to this Play be Gen'rous, Juſt, and Kind.

list.item: Sir Tho. Beamont, Uncle to Beamont and Lucinda. Mr. Betterton.

Sharper, A Man of the Town. Mr. Cibber.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Lucinda, Niece to Sir Tho. in Love with Beamont. Mrs. Bracegirdle.
Iſabella, An Heireſs, in Love with Beamont, but contracted by her Father to Sir Charles in her Childhood. Mrs. Oldfield.

div.head: ACT I.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Sharper, and Equipage his Man.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: AS I was ſaying, Sir, I have advanc'd the Expences of our Summers Expedition from Epſom to Tunbridge, from Tunbridge to the Bath, and from thence to London here; where inſtead of Board-wages, I have liv'd upon Hopes that ſome of theſe Places wou'd furniſh you with a Bubble, and me with my Money; but I ſee no appearance of it: Therefore pray let you and I diſcount.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Prithee, Equipage, have but Patience to ſee what this Winter produces.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p:
No, Sir; the Affront you put upon me at Tunbridge I can't forget, when you had loſt fifty Guineas to the Knight upon Honour, and pretended you had ſent
me Poſt to London to your Scrutore for the Money, and that I had robb'd you and run away with your Keys; when you ordered me to keep out of the way till he had left the Town.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Thou know'ſt I had no other quibble to avoid paying the Debt, and quitting the Place with Honour: Come, don't reflect upon my Misfortune; we have ſeen better Summers.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: In troth, Sir, I thought Bath promis'd well; I am ſure 'twas very full of Company; and if you had not fallen in Love, you might have paid me out of the Subſcription.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How muſt I have liv'd like a Gentleman then, Sirrah? I ſhall break your Head.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: I have done upon that Subject, Sir; I only deſire my Diſcharge and Wages; that's all.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Do you know what you ask, Equipage? A Gameſter and a Soldier are both Sons of Fortune; now to quit my Service, is directly to embroil your ſelf with Fortune.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: I have been embroil'd with her from the firſt Day I enter'd into your Service: But I thank my Stars I am above Fortune, and deſign to forſake the World.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, forſake the World!

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have lately made ſome moral Reflections on the Uncertainty of worldly Pleaſures. I am weary of being well beaten, and ill fed; of paſſing the Night at a Tavern Door, and the Day in carrying Meſſages from one Miſs to another. In ſhort, Sir, I am weary of the ſubſervient Title, without the ſubſervient Money, and reſolve to marry; that is, when I can find a Woman that deſerves me.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: A difficult matter truly.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p:
So it is, Sir; but this Digreſſion makes you forget that there is a ſmall Rule in Arithmetick to be adjuſted. I have ſerv'd you theſe eight Years at twenty-five
Crowns a Year, which in plain Engliſh is forty-two Pounds Sterling; of which I have received now and then a broken Pate: Nevertheleſs there remains two and forty Pounds; which I deſire you'd give me immediately, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Two and Forty Pounds—a great deal of Money—eight Years Service; Mercy upon me! How have I had Patience to endure this Dog ſo long?

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: How have I had Patience to ſtay thus long for my Wages?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Are not you a Rogue, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: And deſerve to be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: As Affairs ſtands now it ſeems. Whilſt I was ſilent I was a very honeſt Fellow; but now I ask for my Wages, I'm fit for the Gallows: Faith, Sir, you might be a Duke by your Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Well, Sirrah, you know I am good natur'd; hang me if I am not very unwilling to part with thee: I will not turn thee away, go get my Cloak.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Turn me away! why, 'tis not you that turn me away; 'tis I that turn you away, if you go to that.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Well, well, we won't diſpute about that; thou ſhalt not leave me.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to pay me then; for I deſign the Money for my Wife's Jointure: Look ye, Sir, here's the Receipt ready.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: The Devil's in the Fellow, I think; thy Noddle runs of nothing but thy own Buſineſs; prithee let's think a little of mine. Mrs. Brazen the Match-maker, is to help me to a Somerſetſhire Widow worth fifty thouſand Pound; ſhe's juſt come to Town.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: But pray, Sir, conſider my Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I tell you, I am in haſte to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: 'Tis done in one word, Sir; my Wages.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Well, ſince you are ſo reſolute, we will part, tho' it trouble me never ſo much. Give me the Receipt: Let's ſee how you have drawn it.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: There, Sir. [Gives it him.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Now begon; I diſcharge you.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: But my Wages, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ah, Equipage, Equipage, the parting with thee ſoftens me even into Tears. If I ſtay I ſhall unman my ſelf: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: The Devil! did not I know him well enough not to truſt him with the Receipt till I had the Money? But, egad, I'll be even with him one way, I'll have his cowardly Bones well beaten, if my Project takes.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: I can't imagine from whence proceeds this change. You that us'd to love Parks, Plays, Balls, Drawing-Rooms, Picquet, Baſlett, and ſuch nice Converſation: You'd not endure my Lady Lockup, becauſe ſhe entertain'd you with nothing but railing at her Servants; of their Waſte, and her good Houſe-wifery; nor Mr. Self-love, becauſe he always got to the Glaſs before you; my Lady Wrinkle laid on too much White, and my Lady Blouze too much Red, and Mrs. Coquet engroſs'd the whole Company: My Lady Prattle fill'd your Ears with the Beauty and Wit of her Children.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: And is there any thing ſo diſagreeable on Earth, as the Sayings of Miſs and Maſs repeated: But what of all this?

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Why then, I wrack my poor Brain in finding out why you ſpend ſo much time with your Country Couſin, Mrs. Dowdy; who is the very reverſe of every thing you us'd to admire.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Charity, Toylet, perfect Charity. You know my aukward Couſin wants Inſtructions: She's left a rich Widow, and comes to London on purpoſe to Dreſs and make a Figure.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Born and bred in Somerſetſhire; never five Miles from Home before, wore the Cloath of her own Spinning, dain'd to make her own Butter, paid the Labourers their Wages on Work-days, and took a Jigg with them on Holy-days. She will make a Figure indeed, by that time the Faſhion-mungers have done with her. Pardon me, Madam, if I can't help thinking you have ſome ſtronger Motive than Charity.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: What does your Wiſdom gueſs?

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Why truly, Madam, I ſhould gueſs your Ladyſhip may have ſome ſmall Pulſe for the handſome young Officer that Mrs. Dowdy is ſo much affraid you ſhould ſee, and thruſt you into the Bed-Chamber, when he came into the Dining-Room: I remember with what Fury you catch'd up the red-hot Poker, and burnt a Hole through the Door to look at him: Belvil, I think they call his Name.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p:
Upon my Life thou haſt hit it, Girl; I'll not conceal my Plot, ſince I deſign thee Chief Inſtrument. • f you remember, I told you that five Years ſince I was in France; and my Mother's Siſter being of the Romiſh Perſwaſion, had enter'd her ſelf among the Auguſtines in Paris: She over-perſwaded me to Board there too, hoping (I ſuppoſe) from her endeavours to make me quit my Religion, and profeſs my ſelf a Nun: During my aboad there, this very Gentleman us'd to make me frequent Viſits at the Grate; the firſt time I ſaw him he came a long with another
that paid a Compliment to a young Lady of the ſame Convent: Our Acquaintance held near two Months. 'Twas then, Toylet, that I felt the force of Love, but not without a thouſand Proteſtations of the ſame from him. But my Father hearing of my Aunts deſign, and apprehending my Youth, (for I was then not full ſixteen) might be prevail'd upon to change my Faith, ſent for me to England in ſuch haſte, that I was not permitted to ſtay one Hour in the Monaſtery after the Meſſenger arrived; ſo had no opportunity to inform Belvil of my Departure.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: I preſume you've kept a Correſpondence ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: No, I knew not how to direct to him; he told me he had been bred in the Spaniſh-Netherlands, and came to France only for his Pleaſure: His Parents (he ſaid) were Engliſh, and he ſpoke the Language very well.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Nor did not you inform him of your Family?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: He often preſt it, and I promis'd to ſatisfie him; but my Father's unexpected Commands broke all our Meaſures; and from that Day, till I ſaw him here, I never heard of him.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: And what is your Deſign now, Madam? I fear he is a Man of Gallantry; beſides you know he makes love to your Couſin; you cannot love him ſtill ſure?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Indeed I do; nay more, can love nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: What will you do with Sir Charles Richley then? who your Father upon his Death-Bed enjoyn'd you to marry, whom he contracted you to in your Childhood.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I cannot love him; it was in my Nonage, and the Barter's illegal; and therefore I'll not Mind it; beſides I'm inform'd he is in Love elſewhere, and cares as little for me as I for him; and I would not be a Wife i'th' Mode.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: In my Opinion, Sir Charles has all the Accompliſhments of his Sex, and a fair Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I own it; but I have a whimſical Heart, not to be touch'd with Jointures and Settlements.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: And if I have any skill in Faces, Belvil is a general Lover.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: No matter; my Conqueſt will be the greater to get him from them all; beſides, I will run any risk to break this unreaſonable Contract.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: What you pleaſe, Madam; I am ready to convey a Letter or a Meſſage to him.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: No, I have a Stratagem to try his Temper, and fathom his Inclinations, I do not intend to diſcover my ſelf to him, till I have him within my Power, beyond a poſſibility of retreat. Come in with me, and I'll give thee a full Relation, and prepare our ſelves for my deſign.

head.hi: The SCENE Changes to Belvil's Lodgings, Belvil in a Night-Gown playing on a Flute; he lays it down and looks upon his Watch.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis time to Dreſs. Robin.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Things.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Here's a Letter for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: [Takes it and looks on it, then gives it him again.] Lay it by.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Won't you read it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, I know the Hand. Egad, it is as hard to get rid of a Citizen's Wife, when liſted in her Service, as Subſiſtance out of the Hand of an Agent, who is juſt ſetting up his Coach: She's as troubleſome as a Dun when our Stock's exhauſted.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Here's another Letter, Sir; and the Footman ſtays for an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Lucinda's Character! Slave, how durſt you defer my Joy ſo long?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, ever whilſt you live the ſweeteſt Bit for the laſt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Reads.] The Brightneſs of the Day tempts me to a Morning's Walk; if you've an Inclination, you'll find me in the Park at Twelve, Lucinda. An Inclination! Yes, I have an Inclination; I wiſh you would gratifie it. Bid the Footman wait; I'll ſend an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: So, Mrs. Peeper; what News from Somerſetſhire?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Somerſetſhire, Manners; you ſhou'd have ſaid St. James's; for my Lady is as great a Belle as the beſt of 'em, I aſſure you that.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A Belle! ſo is a Broom-ſtick.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Carry this Letter to the Footman. Well, Mrs. Peeper, what Affair brings you?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: I come from my Lady, Sir: She—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Dreſſing himſelf.] Robin, my Coat.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Is Impatient till ſhe ſees you: All the Trades in the Creation are employ'd in her Dreſs; ſhe ſpares no Art to charm you; there's Milleners, Mantua-makers, Tirewomen, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Watch.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Amongſt a Crowd of Compleaters, a Match, maker has ſhuffled in, and propoſes one Sir John Sharper to her; if you are cold you'll loſe her, upon my Virginity, you will.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Sword.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Ha! how careleſs you are; what, not a Word? In Truth, I don't know where you'll find ſuch another Fool, as my Miſtreſs, with Fifty Thouſand Pound.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Perriwigg.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Sure, if you don't value my Lady, you might anſwer me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Handkercher and Snuff-Box. So am I well now, Mrs. Peeper? [Adjuſting himſelf.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Well: Ah! Nature has been but too kind to you. But, Sir, concerning my Lady; you know I am entirely in your Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why then to be ſincere with thee, I never did, nor never ſhall care Three-pence for her, without one thing.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: But her Fortune, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Shall never tempt me to marry her at a venture.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: No! why then to what purpoſe do you court her? 'Tis calling your Gallanty in queſtion to ſuſpect an Intreague.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No faith, Peeper, my deſign is quite another thing; and if thou wou'dſt aſſiſt me—

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: In any thing, Sir, within my Power.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou! there then [Gives her Money.] When we wou'd have a Lawyer plead heartily, we muſt not forget his Fee.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: You are ſo generous, that to keep up the Simile, Lawer-like, I'll ſpare no Breath to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: But don't you carry the Simile too far, and take Bribes on both ſides.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: I ſcorn it. Inſtruct me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Find ſome way to perſuade her to let me ſee the Writings of her Eſtate; tell her 'tis the only way to fix me; for what ever we ſay in Commendation of your Sex, Beauty, Shape, Wit, and ſo forth, is but the Fable; the Moral is the Money, Girl.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: But you won't marry her you ſay, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Not till I am ſatisfied what ſhe's worth, my Dear; but theſe Writings muſt be ſeen: Upon Honour, it
ſhall turn as much to your Account, whether I marry her or not.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Nay then—Well, Sir, it ſhall be done; when will you prove it?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Two Hours hence.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: What, juſt upon the Wing? I'm glad I've nick't the time, and find you without Company.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, have you Secrets to impart? Robin, leave us. [Exit Robin.] Come, come, diſcloſe ſome warm, wiſhing, kind, conſenting Fair: Or is it a plump, ſoft, wholeſome Country Girl thou woud'ſt conſign over to thy Friend. 'm not nice, nor care who plucks the Roſe I ſmell to, provided it has not loſt its ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Sure thou thinkeſt the Buſineſs of the World is converted into Wenching.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'm ſure there's no pleaſure in that Buſineſs where a Woman is not concern'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: A Woman is the Subject. But ſuch a Woman.

l.hi: Bright as the Morn, when firſt the World began,
And I am doom'd to be the happy Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I fear ſo, Belvil.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then ſhe is in Love with me? where does ſhe live? what's her Name? how dignify'd or diſtinguiſh'd? by Miſtreſs, Madam, or Right Honourable—Maid, Wife or Widow? Quick, quick diſcloſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: 'Tis Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Devil! have you rais'd my expectation to this height, then pall me with an Acquaintance? But what of her?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: You brought me into the Danger; I came wounded off, and have no hopes of Cure, but from your roving Temper. You weigh the Sex alike, and without a Pang may give me leave to try my Fortune with her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This comes of carrying a Friend to ſee one's Miſtriſs. Why, I thought you had been engag'd from your Childhood. Come will you be upon the ſquare, bring me to your Miſtriſs; if I like her as well as I do Lucinda, perhaps we may agree upon the change.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I will: ſhe cannot fail to charm thee; all Eyes, but mine, adore her: And ſure 'twas the Malice of our Stars caus'd our Fathers to conclude the Match, where Intereſt only held the Scale, and gentle Love fled from either ſide: But be ſerious. How far are you engag'd with Lucinda?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Faith, 'tis a kind of intricate Story, but you muſt be ſatisfied. I have been bred a Soldier of Fortune, and am to this Day ignorant who my Parents were. The Man who took care of me, always told me England was my Native Country, taught me the Language; and for ought I know, ſome travelling Prince begot me: My Foſter-Father was in Battle kill'd, and never gave me farther Light: I had ſtill an Inclination to ſee this Country.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: This Story ſeems Romantick—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You'll think it ſo before I have done: Being landed, and travelling with my Servant towards London, I loſt my way; Night came on; when, at a diſtance, we diſcovered Lights and made up to 'em. It proved Lucinda's Country Houſe: Her Uncle, Sir Thomas Beamont, kindly receiv'd and entertain'd us.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Lucky Chance!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
So it prov'd to them; for that very Night her Houſe was beſet with Thieves: Their number muſt have prevail'd but for our unexpected Aid; we beat them off, preſerv'd their Wealth, and perhaps their Lives. The Lady
expreſs'd a thouſand Thanks. The old Man grew Inquiſitive, who I was, and whence I came. I frankly told him the Story of my Life: He ſtood amaz'd, and ask'd me fifty Queſtions, and ſeem'd ſurpriz'd at every Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Well; and what enſu'd upon that?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, he has ever ſince been mighty fond of me, and forc'd Money upon me, which I could ſcarcely make him take my Note for.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: You're eſtabliſh'd every way; his kindneſs promotes you Intereſt with his Niece.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Quite contrary: His generous Carriage has oblig'd me to ſwear to him, never to attempt to marry her, if ſhe ſhould conſent without his leave, which he ſeems ſtill averſe to. I confeſs I love her beyond the reſt of her Sex, except one I ſaw thro' a Grate in France, that I could never hear of ſince: yet this reſtraint keeps me from preſſing my Suit for Marriage, and I have too much reſpect to attempt the other.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Does ſhe know the Injunction?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No; that he forbad me too—Beſides, ſhe is devoted to Platonick Notions

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I never mind that in a handſome Woman: This generous Declaration draws another Queſtion, why do you addreſs Mrs. Dowdy?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That's another Injunction of the old Gentleman's, to procure the Writings of an Eſtate out of her Hands, that her Husband cheated a Relation of his of. You ſee, Sir Charles, I have a World of Buſineſs cut out, and have made you entirely my Confident: No foul play; do ye hear?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p:
There can be none with a Prince that aims at univerſal Monarchy. But ſetting Love apart, laſt Night after you left us, there came a Fellow into the Chocolate-Houſe, who pretended he had made a Campaign in the Nature of a Voluntier; and amongſt a number of palpable
Lyes, ſwore, at the Battle of Blenheim, he purſu'd a French General over the Danube, and took him Priſoner on the other ſide, then brought him over upon his Back; the Enemies Cannon playing at him all the while: The Company laugh'd: I confeſs it rais'd my Spleen, and I cou'd not forbear ſaying, That Action was too Glorious in it ſelf to want a Romance to illuſtrate it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So I ſuppoſe you brought a ſquabble upon your Hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: No; he ſwore, look'd big, bluſter'd, and walk'd off.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Sir Charles, here's a Porter with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Sir, a Gentleman that ſaw you come in here, bid me give you this.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: [Peruſes the Letter.] Very well, I'll come to him: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Him! what, 'tis not a Challenge I hope? I muſt go with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Suppoſe it true, 'tis not fair to carry a ſecond when the Inviter names none. But 'tis no ſuch thing: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If this ſhou'd be a Duel now—I cou'd never forgive my ſelf for letting him go alone, eſpecially if he comes to any harm.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why; ſuppoſe he ſhould be kill'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Raſcal, I had rather ſuppoſe you hang'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A ſudden Death prevents a great deal of Vexation, Sir, ſometimes

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How do you make that out?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p:
Why, when a Man takes his ſick Bed, the ſad Formalitics that attend it, are more dreadful than Death it ſelf: His Friends and Relations all weeping round his
Bed; a Lawyer, brib'd by his Spouſe to urge the Will: That made, the Sorrow is finiſh'd; each then enquire after their Legacy: And the diſconſolate Wife having borrowed a Weed of her Neighbour, is conſulting her Glaſs to ſee how it becomes her. Her Thoughts are where to find another Husband; the Servants Heads full of their Mourning: So that if the dying Man calls for a Cordial; ſlap, they give him a Bolous—He deſires to be rais'd—They pull away the Pillow.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: The Doctor, whoſe Preſcription has poiſon'd him, orders a double Doſe of Opium, to ſmooth his Paſſage to the other World; takes his two Guineas Fee, throws himſelf into his Chariot, and bids his Coachman drive on to the next Patient. Now, Sir, a Builet, or an Oilet-hole in the Guts prevents all this.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You muſt preach this when we are raiſing Recruits, Sirrah; Ha, ha. But I muſt to the Park to meet Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! if you are a Gentleman protect me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha! from what, Madam. Egad, I ſhall be famous for delivering diſtreſs'd Dam'ſels.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Purſu'd by an old jealous Husband, whom I married by my Friends Command, when I had given my Heart and Vows to another; he begg'd for one kind parting Hour; which I, in pity, granted: But, Oh! the illfated Moment brought both my Husband and my Father to be Spectators of our Meeting; they call'd for help to ſeize him, but he leapt the Balcony; and in the Buſtle I eſcaped with my Woman, but know not whither.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what a Story has ſhe patch'd up.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fear not, Madam, I'll defend you againſt all the Fathers and Husbands in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And I will take your Ladiſhip's Woman into my Protection.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If your Face anſwers your Shape and Mien, I cannot blame your Husband's Fears: Convince me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: After what I have told you, if you are generous, you will not ask to ſee my Face. Give me but Sanctuary here till Night, ſhall favour my eſcape to a Friend's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Command it, Madam—Robin, a Curſe of Fortune, to ſend me a Collation at home, when I'm engag'd abroad: But I muſt not diſappoint Lucinda. Madam, Buſineſs of the laſt Conſequence calls me out; but my return ſhall be ſudden. Can I ſerve you, by enquiring if the Storm be over?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: By no means: enquiry wou'd ruin me. At your return, perhaps I may inform you more.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Humph! that was kindly inſinuated—Robin, give Orders that no Perſon be admitted into my Lodgings in my abſence. Madam, your moſt humble.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Well, Madam, what's your next Project? The Gentleman ſhew'd but little Curioſity. 'Tis certainly an Aſſignation that hurried him hence—Or he had been more preſſing to have ſeen your Face; and if he had, he wou'd infallibly have remember'd you, and then your Plot wou'd have been ſpoil'd.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible: For having had the Small-Pox ſince, I am perſwaded he will not know me. He ſays he will return inſtantly; in the mean time I'll view his Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Toy,
sp.p: To what end will you ſtay? 'Tis ten to one if he comes back theſe ſix Hours.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: No matter; I reſolve to finiſh what I once begin. I'll

l.hi: Purſue his Steps, and trace 'em with ſuch Art,
Diſcover all the Secrets of his Heart:
The Petty Tyrants by my Plots dethrone,
And there erect an Empire of my own.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt ACT.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: WHAT ſhou'd be the reaſon of Belvill's ſtay, Betty? I wiſh I had not ſent to him, I'm very uneaſie: How calm my Hours were before I knew this Man.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I thought Platonick Love never diſturb'd the Mind, Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, when the Friendſhip is nice and particular.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I never knew Friendſhip in different Sexes but came to particulars at laſt: See here he is.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: So the bright Cyprian Goddeſs moves,

l.hi: When looſe, and in her Chariot drawn by Doves,
She rides to meet the War-like God ſhe loves.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hey; what Lady have you laviſh'd your Wit upon this Morning, that you are forc'd to Trade upon other Mens Stocks?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hang theſe Poetical Rogues, they publiſh every pretty Thought, that a Gentleman's forc'd to borrow to expreſs his own Notions.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray how do ye apply the laſt Line, Belvill?
—To meet the warlike God ſhe loves.
You may be vain enough to think your ſelf a Mars—
But when did I betray the Weakneſs of a Venus?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: S'life Madam! I ask your Pardon, this villainous Love is got into my Heart, and dictates ſo faſt to my Tongue, I had quite forgot your Platonicks.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And our Articles laſt Night too I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ah! the Study's as crabbed as the Law—And the Practice as unpleaſant as Pennance. Imprimis, that I muſt take Pains to make the World underſtand our Converſation is only Friendſhip, and tho' no Body will believe me—Swear I admire the Beauties of your Mind—without regarding thoſe of your Perſon—Proteſt I have no deſire to Kiſs thoſe roſie Lips—preſs that ſoft white Hand—and Sigh my Soul, out in your Boſome—
[Lucinda aſide,] The Devil! How the Fellow talks—

[To him,] All this you muſt poſitively obſerve—But then conſider the freedoms I allow Ballances the reſtraint. I promiſe you all publick Marks of my Favour; my Conduct is ſincere and open, I hate a falſe Prude who won't know a Gentleman in Company, tho' three Hours before ſhe had held private Conference with him in her Bed-chamber; that ſolemnly declares ſhe never writ or receiv'd a Billet doux in her Life, and knows at the ſame time ſhe keeps a Woman on purpoſe for the Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Like your reforming Ladies, who all the while they are giving a young Fellow advice againſt Wenching, their Looks ſlyly inſinuate a liking to his Perſon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Or Mrs. Prim the Poetical She-Philoſopher, whoſe Diſcourſe and Writings are fill'd with Honour and ſtrict Rules of Virtue; that vows ſhe cou'd not Sleep if ſhe was
guilty of one criminal Thought—yet is terribly wrong'd if ſhe has not twice ſlipt aſide for a natural Tympany.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! How I hate the noiſe of Virtue in my Ears from a Woman—whom I know lives by Vice; and 'tis a Maxim with me—That ſhe who rails moſt, yields ſooneſt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have the ſame Opinion of thoſe Men, who boaſt much of their Secrecy, only for an opportunity to gain ſomething to betray—Well, I think our Sentiments agree, therefore I hope you ſubmit to the Conditions.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: When one has given a Tyrant Power 'tis Prudence to obey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hold; One thing more; During this League you muſt Addreſs no other Woman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Devil! You'l next preſcribe my Eating, Drinking, Sleeping, Walking—Nay, even Thinking! Madam, I ſuppoſe you have read of Aeſop's Ox. S'death! Madam I am of Cowly's Mind, when I am all Soul, I ſhall keep your Rules.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, don't believe I am jealous, but it wou'd touch my Pride, to have it ſaid the Man that I eſteem'd worthy to be ſeen with—was Miſtreſs ſuch a Ones conqueſt—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So by what I can diſcover, you'd have me have no other Affair upon my Hands, but waiting upon you to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To no purpoſe! Is not Friendſhip the nobleſt Aim of human Kind?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Had your Parents thought ſo, the World had never known your Charms, Ha, ha, ha. Well, but when I have Sworn all this, what Tye have I upon you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh you need not fear me—I have an indifference to your whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Heigh, ho! [Sighs.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why do you Sigh?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Only reflecting upon the deſperate Caſe of a Friend of mine, who confeſs'd to me half an Hour ago he was dying for Love of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dying for me! Who is it Belvill?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, my Platonick Lady, hang me if I tell you—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, let it alone—I care not—I think I am weary with walking; you have often Importun'd me to ſee the Collection of Pictures you brought over. Come, my Maid's with me, I'le go now and Drink ſome Tea with you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! What a time ſhe has choſe now—Robin, Zounds—what ſhall we do with the Woman that is at home?[aſide to Robin.]

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ah pox of Ill-luck; Choak me If I know Sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's that Whiſper? He ſhan't ſtir a ſtep before me—I'll have nothing but Tea.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Dear Madam, let him go, he, he, he, he, ſha, ſha, ſhall only get a little Jelly or Sweet-meats or ſo—Robin, Sirrah, lock her into your Garret. [Aſide to Robin.]

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: It ſhall be done Sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ſay it ſhall not be done Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Then we are all undone Sir. [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I hate Sweet-meats in a Morning, 'twill ſpoil my Dinner—There's ſomething more; I read Confuſion in his Face. [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But Mrs. Betty does I'm ſure—Pray let him go.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I tell you no Scout ſhall go before—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What ſhall I do—Oh Sir, why you forget Sir Charles, whom you reſolv'd to prevent Fighting the Duel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is a new-born Lye—I'll humour it, but reſolve to find it out. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: True, but this Lady makes me forget all other Friends.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To preſerve Sir Charles is of greater conſequence than my Viſit, I'll defer that till ſome other time; you'l ſee me to my Coach.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Rogue has brought me off—Tho' I hope Sir Charles is in no Danger. [aſide.] I wou'd not loſe the pleaſure of your kind Intention: Let it be to Morrow Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'll think on't; Come—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: So here's a Guinea ſlap, for my Maſter always rewards my Politicks.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: The Devil! Never Man was ſo drawn in •• a Kicking certainly—Ah hang Dog—
Are you there? You are always out of the way when you ſhou'd do a Body any Service.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Service, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ay Service Sir: I was appointed to meet a pretty Lady in Hide-Park, and being there before her Hour, comes me up a bluſtering Fellow, who pretending I had ſent him a Challenge, drew upon me, ſo I was oblig'd to Fight him; and Egad if I had not underſtood Fencing very well, I had been whipt thro' the Lungs, for he had a curſed long Reach—but I cloſed in with him, tripp'd up his Heels, took away his Sword, and gave him his Life.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Oh the damn'd Lye—This was a Plot of my contrivance, and I have ſeen him fairly Kick'd. [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What's that you mutter?

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: I was ſaying to my ſelf, Sir, 'twas very unfortunate, for ten to one but you'd loſt the Lady by it.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Egad and ſo I did, for ſhe ſhriek'd out, and drove away like the Devil, when ſhe ſaw us engag'd.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Where will his Lyes end [aſide] She was very hard Hearted Sir, not to ſend her Coach-man to part ye.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: And diſcover our Intreague.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: True, I'd forgot that—Well, Sir, you know I ſtill follow in hopes of my Wages.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I owe you none, Sirrah; Han't I a Receipt to ſhew—however becauſe you are ſometimes an uſeful—Raſcal you ſhall ſtay with me, and partake my good Fortune; I expect an Emiſſary with News about the rich Widow I was telling you of.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Shall I believe him or no—if there were any hopes I'd ſtick cloſe [Aſide] Nay, Sir, you know what an Affection I have for you—

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Yes, you Dog, I know it full well—but conveniency ſometimes makes a Man of Honour pocket Affronts.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: What have I done Sir?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Sirrah, you might have kept me out of the Chocolate-Houſe when I was Drunk laſt Night, and brought this Quarrel upon my Hands.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Oh Sir! But as long as you Conquer'd your Man—

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Peace, here comes Mrs. Brazen.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: A fit Companion by my Troth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Good Morrow noble Squire.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: My Genius, my better Angel! well how fares my buxſome Widow, ha?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Fortune ſmiles upon my Lad of Iron. I have been with her all this Morning, and I have prais'd thee from Head to Foot—I have ſet her a Gog I'll warrant thee Boy.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Did you touch upon my Courage?

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: His Courage! Ah, in what Latitude does that lie? [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Thy Valour Boy! I ſaid thou wert a meer Hercules, Man both in Love and War! I told her you had a large Eſtate, and you were of the antient Family of the O Sharpers in Ireland, dear Joy.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Pox, why in Ireland?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Oh! becauſe the Iriſh-Men carry away all the Fortunes—I ſaid you kept your own Coach too.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I hope you ſaid I had left it in my own Country then—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: No, no, here Man—I can help thee to a Coach Boy from the Knights to my Lord Dukes: Why, 'tis my Buſineſs I tell thee; if there were occaſion I can have half a dozen Foot-men in Liveries too.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Heark ye Miſtreſs—obſerve my Stature—Humph—A'n't I a handſome Fellow? [Setting himſelf out]
Help me to a Fortune now, and you ſhall go halves.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Say you ſo? I'll put you down in my Book; you are not the firſt Servant I have rais'd to a Lady's Bed—as 'tis well known in this Town. [Puts him down in her Book.]

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: But when muſt I ſee her Mrs. Brazen? I am Impatient.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p:
See her—but look ye Squire you know the Conditions, when ſhall we Sign and Seal—for you'l grant I muſt live out of my honeſt Endeavours. I'm ſure I take a great deal of Pains for my Thouſand Pounds—up early and down late—then Mercy on me, how do I
ſtretch my Conſcience when I am ſetting out one of you young Rogues!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: But are you ſure ſhe'l have me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Sure? I can perſwade them to any thing let me come at 'em. Heark ye under the Roſe, 'tis a Receipt of mine has prevailed with all the old Women to marry of late—

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Away! Let's to the Tavern, and over a Cup of mull'd Sack ſeal to thy Demands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: With all my Heart—Come Sirrah, hold up your Head, you are in my Book you Rogue, and that's the High Road to Preferment, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Along then. A hey for Little Equipage.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: What think you now Madam—cou'd any thing but a Miſtreſs make him guilty of ſuch Ill-manners, to leave a Lady in diſtreſs ſo long—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Moſt certain—my Patience is quite worn out—I muſt go.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Dear Madam, ſince we have efcap'd hitherto undiſcover'd, think of him no more.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Don't you trouble your ſelf about that, I ſhan't give him over thus—but do you get me a Chair.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
Let me examine my ſelf a little. What have I undertaken here—A duce of too much Liberty—If my old Dad had been alive, I durſt not have gone a Rover hunting thus. Do I value Reputation—Yes, as much as any Body does—that follows their Inclination—
Ay, but whether will that Inclination carry me? Why, not beyond the Rules of Honour, and then—a Fig for the Cenſure of the World, I ſay—Oh! Here he comes. [Claps on her Mask.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now Madam I am entirely yours, pray oblige me with your Commands. I hope you have not been diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: No way but by my Grief Sir—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I long to ſee her Face. [Aſide.] Baniſh Grief, you are here ſecure, lay by Conſtraint—and venture to Unmask—Sparkling Eyes—Lovely Hair—I ſhall run Mad. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I thought I had had your Promiſe not to ask that.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Promiſe Madam—S'Death, I, I, I, faith Madam; I won't tell your Husband, if I happen to know him.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Indeed—Indeed, I ſhan't put it in your Power.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Robin, run call out Fire—Thieves, or the Devil—That ſhe may drop her Mask in the Surprize.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes Sir, yes Sir, Sir, [Goes and comes back.]
Here's Sir Charles coming up.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir Charles! I am undone. [Aſide.]
For Heaven's ſake, Sir, give me leave to retire; if I am ſeen, I'm ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In, in quickly. [Runs in.]
Oh! Sir Charles, I have been in ſome Apprehenſions for you, tho' you ſeem'd to diſguiſe the Matter; it was a Duel: Ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Something like it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I ſee thy Sword has not fail'd thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No, nor my Shoes neither! I have us'd them pretty fairly ſince I went out—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In Walking?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No in Kicking—'twas the very numerical Coward I told thee of—at the Chocolate-Houſe—When I bid him draw, he ſwore he came to meet a Lady and was not prepar'd for Fighting—deny'd the Challenge, and provok'd me to a warm Breathing. And this was the end of my Adventure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I'll be hang'd if 'twas not Mr. Sharper.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: The very ſame—a Gentleman told me ſo as I came out of the Park. But prethee Belvill let me go into thy Dreſſing-Room, to put my ſelf a little in Order, after this Heat; Come Robin help me. [Going in.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold! [Stops him.]

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter? You han't a Wench there have you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, then I wou'd not ſtop you, but 'tis a Woman of Condition.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How my Blood chills—'tis Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The ſame; She had a Mind to ſee my Pictures, I know not if ſhe is willing to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Sir. Char.
sp.p: You are a Happy Man—Adieu.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir Charles, I am glad to ſee you in Safety; Belvill left me abruptly—to prevent a Duel he ſaid you were ingag'd in—I reſolv'd to follow and inquire after it. [Sir. Charles going off meets Lucinda and Betty, they both ſtart.]

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I am happy if I created the leaſt Concern in you, Madam. Heark ye Belvill, doubtleſs you miſtook the Lady's Name within [Aſide to Belvill.]

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Confuſion! She here? Then I am caught.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, Sir Charles, all Danger over; now for the Pictures.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What the Devil ſhall I ſay. [Aſide.]

Faith Madam you have ſurpriz'd me a little, Batchellor's Lodgings are ſeldom in Order—pleaſe to take one turn in the Garden, and they ſhall be prepar'd for you. Dear Charles bring me off this once, and I'll tell you all hereafter. [Aſide to Sir Charles.]

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Come Madam, there's as many Curioſities in the Garden, as in the Gallery; let him ſet his Things in Order, ha, ha. [Slyly.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Make haſt then for my Uncle will ſtay Dinner. [Going.]

div.stage: Enter Toylet Mask'd. Running to Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Madam there's a Chair—I was ſtop'd—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sweet-heart I want no Chair, my Coach is here.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Oh wretched! What have I done now? [amaz'd.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ah! The Devil wou'd not let me 'ſcape—thus— [Aſide confounded.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So, I apprehend the Diſorder of your Rooms now Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ha, ſure 'tis Toylet's Voice—then ſhe within ſhou'd be Iſabella—if I muſt Marry her my Honour is concern'd, and I ſhall have occaſion for my Sword in earneſt—I'll to her Houſe this Moment, e're I upbraid him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Perfidious Man—to uſe ſuch Artifice to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I confeſs it has a Face againſt me, but give me leave, and I will tell you the whole Story—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Say you ſo, but I'll prevent that— [Iſabella peeping.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No Sir, you need not, her ſelf will do it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Gad, with all my Heart— [Walking about in a Paſſion.]

Let her tell the plain Truth—
How came you here Madam?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: How came I here, why was it not your own Appointment? Are you falſe? Did you not come with Haſt and Rapture, and tell me what Excuſes you had made—to get an Hour the Happieſt of your Life?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: S'death and Hell! What's the meaning of this? Did you not tell me Madam?—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go you are baſe, what Confuſion you are in? Pray Madam what was your Buſineſs here?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: My Buſineſs Madam, the ſame with yours I ſuppoſe; if I had not lov'd him, I had not come hither; and if you had not been Jealous you had not followed us—My Chair waits—and ſo farewel, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Diſtraction! Affronted too—very well, Sir. [Walking about.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Upon my Faith Madam 'tis all a Trick—they are two Devils; was ever Man thus abuſed? Robin run, force them back—I'll unmask them before your Face, and make them confeſs their damn'd Deſign. [Paſſionately.]

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'll bring them back with a Vengeance; put their Shams upon Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Madam hear me but ſpeak—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No! nor ever ſee thee more—for now I am convinc'd there is not one of all thy curſed flattering Race—that is not Perjur'd in his turn.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By all the burning Paſſion in my Breaſt, which I feel your Anger blow yet higher—Theſe Women came—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No matter why nor whence they came—ſince I have ſeen them here—Our Converſation ends, approach me not, for by all the torturing Pangs of jealous Love—for I do find it Love, had I a Dagger I'd fix it in thy Heart or mine, ſooner than think of being reconcil'd

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
'Tis in vain to follow her. So, I thought by my ſelf, what our Platonicks wou'd come to. But who can this
Woman be? She is either ſet on, or elſe Egad ſhe's another Platonick, that has taken a liking to my Perſon too.
Well Sirrah, where are they, what ſaid they, what were they?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Devils, Sir, Devils! I believe they vaniſh'd—for I cou'd not find them—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sirrah you look as if you ly'd.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Faith and ſo I do; I got a Guinea to hold my Tongue. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Raſcal! tell me who they are. [Takes him by the Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Upon my Faith, Sir, I don't know; but to confeſs the Truth Sir, the Maid pull'd her Mask off, She was very pretty—and ſaid She was in Love with me; and her Lady was a great Fortune, and deſperately taken with you Sir: So I thought 'twas pity to Hurt them, Sir, and let them go—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You did ſo Villain, have they ſtole nothing? Find them out again you Dog, or I'll cut your Ears off—I will be juſtify'd—in Love with you, Vermin—I ſhall have a Surgeon's Bill to pay I ſuppoſe before next Campaign, theſe are common Jilts; call me a Chair, I'll to Lucinda's and uſe her Uncle's Intereſt for my Peace—To be thus plagued for nothing, 'twou'd vex a Stoick—S'death had it been a real Intreague, there had been ſome Conſolation in't, I find Lucinda's Rage gives me real Pain.

l.hi: Ask him who moſt affects the Rover's Part,
Careſſing every Fair that will be kind,
If ſome one Woman reigns not in his Heart;
And is the Sovereign Miſtreſs of his Mind.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: ACT III.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Dowdy, Mrs. Brazon the Match-maker, Mrs. Wheedle the Milliner, Mrs. Turnup the Manto-Maker, Mrs. Criſpit the Tire-Woman, and Peeper her Maid—They all ſeem Talking to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy,
sp.p: We'l, we'l la you now, la you now Shour and Shour you'l Gally me.

sp.speaker: Turnup,
sp.p: Here's your Ladyſhips Manto and Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy,
sp.p: Ladyſhip, why what a main difference is here between this Town and the Country—I was never call'd above Forſooth in all my Life—Mercy on me, why you ha ſpoil'd my Petticoat mun, zee Peeper, She has cut it in a Thouſand Bits.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh, that's the Faſhion, theſe are Furbelows Madam—'tis the prettieſt made Coat—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Furbelow's, a murrain take 'em, they ſpoil all the Zilk—good ſtrange, ſhour London Women do nothing but ſtudy Vaſhions, they never mind their Dairy I warant 'em.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Ladies have no other employment for their Brain—and our Art lies in hiding the defects of Nature—Furbelows upwards, were deviſed for thoſe that have no Hips, and too large ones, brought up the full-bottom'd Furbelows.

sp.speaker: Millin.
sp.p: And a long Neck and a hollow Breaſt, firſt made uſe of the Stinkirk—and here's a delicate one for your Ladyſhip—I have a Book in my Pocket juſt come from France, Intituled, The Elements of the Toylet—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Doud.
sp.p: Elements, mercy on me! what do they get up into the Sky now?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: A Learned Author to be ſure—let me ſee that Mrs. Wheedle.

sp.speaker: Millin.
sp.p: Here Mrs. Peeper, 'tis the Second Volume; the Firſt only ſhews an Alphabetical Index of the moſt notable Pieces which enter into the Compoſition of a Comode.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowd.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall ne'er mind theſe hard Names; Oh Sirs, Peeper, what ſwinging Cathedral Headgeer is this?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh, Modiſh French Night-Clothes; Madam, what's here—all ſorts of Dreſſes painted to the Life—Ha, ha, ha, Head-cloaths to ſhorten the Face—Favorites to raiſe the Forehead—to heighten flat Cheeks flying Cornets—four Pinners to help narrow Foreheads and long Noſes, and very forward, to make the Eyes look Languiſhing

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowd.
sp.p: Ay, that Peeper, double it down, Oh, I love Languiſhing. [Puts on an awkward Languiſh.]

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Take it and read it at your leiſure, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: I ſhall never ha done ſhour zeeing all my vine things. [Tumbling her things over.]
Hy day, what's theſe two pieces of Band-Box for?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis Paſt board Madam, for your Ladyſhip's Rump.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: A Rump, ho, ho, ho, has Couſin Isbel a Rump, Peeper?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Certainly Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: If Couſin has one, as I hope to be Kiſs'd—I'll have it Mrs. Turnup.

sp.speaker: Criſpit.
sp.p: Will your Ladyſhip ſit down and let me ſhape your Eye-brows? [She nips her Eye-brows, ſhe flies up and roars out.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Ods fleſh, the Devil's in you, I think, what will you tear all the Hair off? a murrain take ye, an this be your ſhaping.

sp.speaker: Millin.
sp.p: Be pleaſed to put on the Addition Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: What does ſhe mean now? To pull my Skin off mehap next; ha Peper, are theſe your London Vaſhions?

sp.speaker: Peeper.
sp.p: No, no, Addition is only Paint, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Paint Miſtreſs, od I've a good mind to hit you a dows o'th' Chops, zo I have, what de ye take me for a Whore, becauſe I'm come to London, ha? Paint quoth a.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Madam, Women of the firſt Rank think it no Crime to help Nature in the Complexion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Zay you zo? Nay, my Skin was ever counted none of the beſt—well we'll zhut the Door then.

sp.speaker: Millin.
sp.p: There you are in the wrong again, Madam; our Ladies make no ſcruple of letting all the World ſee 'em lay it on—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Well, in my Conſcience and Zoul, they care not what they zhow here—

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Madam, your Dancing-Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: O lack, get all you into the next Room, and ſtay for me there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Madam, you promis'd to hear a word from me about Sir John Sharper—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy,
sp.p: Zo I will by and by.

sp.speaker: Caper.
sp.p: Will your Ladyſhip pleaſe to take a Dance?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Pſhaw, I hate your One, Two, Three, teach me a London Dance mun.

sp.speaker: Caper,
sp.p: I'll lead you a Courant Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Ay, a Rant, with all my Heart, I dan't underſtand the Names, let en be a Dance, and 'tis well enough. [He leads her about.]
Hy, hy, do you call this Dancing? ads heartlikins, in my thoughts 'tis plain Walking; I'll ſhew you one of our Country Dances; play me a Jig. [Dances an awkward Jig.]

sp.speaker: Caper.
sp.p: Oh dear, Madam you'll quite ſpoil your Steps.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Dan't tell me that—I was counted one of the beſt Dancers in all our Pariſh, zo I was

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Ay, round a May-pole—There are Fellows now in this Town ſo wretched, that to purchaſe this Woman's Wealth, wou'd to her Face ſwear ſhe's an Angel.

sp.speaker: Turnup.
sp.p: True; but if they had her once, would uſe her like the Devil— [This while the Dancing-Maſter is ſetting her Arms and Breaſt.]

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Madam, your Singing-Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: O la, I can't Dance no more now.

sp.speaker: Singing-Maſt.
sp.p: Are you ready, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Man.

sp.speaker: Singing-Maſt.
sp.p: Fa, la, mi, Sol.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Louk you Friend, I can't ſpeak Out-landiſh, but I intend to learn; I'm to have a Maſter come.

sp.speaker: Singing-Maſt.
sp.p: This is not Out-landiſh, Madam, 'tis only the Notes to try your Voice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Nay, nay, and that be all, I'll zing you a Zong de ye ſee, and ſhow you my Voice ſhour

lg.l: AS I walk'd forth one May Morning,

l.hi: I heard a pretty Maid ſweetly Sing
As ſhe ſat under the Cow a Milking,

lg.l: Sing I ſhall be Marry'd a Tueſday;
I mun look Smug upon Tueſday.

l.hi: I prithee Sweet-heart what makes thee to Marry,
Is your Maiden-head grown a Burthen to carry?
Or are you afraid that you ſhall Miſcarry?

lg.l: I prithe now tarry till Wedneſday.

l.hi: I pray good Sir, don't wiſh me ſuch ill,
I have kept it theſe Seven Years againſt my own Will;
I have made a Vow, and I will it fulfil,

lg.l: That I will be Marry'd on Tueſday,
So I mun look Smug upon Tueſday.

l.hi: A Tueſday Morn it will be all my care
To pouder my Locks and to curl up my Hair,
And two pretty Maids for to wait on me there;

lg.l: So I mun look Smug upon Tueſday;
So Fine and ſo Smug upon Tueſday.

l.hi: Then two Young Men to the Church will me bring,
Where my Husband will give me a gay Gold Ring,
But at Night he will give me a far better thing;

lg.l: So I mun look Smug upon Tueſday,
So Fine and ſo Smug upon Tueſday.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Madam, you'll not be dreſt in your New Cloaths by that time Captain Belvill comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Ods Fleſh well thought on, I can Learn no more this Morning, [Exit Singing-Maſter.]
But Peeper, when did he zay he'd come?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: In two Hours, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall Charm him zure—odſo, but where's Couſin Bell to day; you muſt vetch her mun to zee my vine Things, ſhe'll tell me an they be vite or not—

sp.speaker: Peeper.
sp.p: Bleſs me Madam, ſhe's gone away to the Bath, in my Lady Flounce's Coach this Morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: How! gone a hundred Mile and ne'er bid one Good bye.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh dear, Madam, London Ladies ne'er ſtand upon Ceremony—why, Sir Charles Richly that is to marry her, knew nothing of it—he was here juſt now to enquire for her, and was extreamly Surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Ad ſhe'll make a rare Wife I'll war rant her—and ſhe has zuch Frolicks—well, but you zay the Captain will come; but an he don't come ſoon, Mrs. Brazon will bring me a Squire, or a Knight, I tell you that.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh Madam, Belvill is the Sweeteſt, Nobleſt Gentleman; beſides, we ſhould Encourage thoſe that Defend us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Nay, for that matter I dan't mind, I like a Zouldier, but not for that Reaſon, de ye zee, there's Conveniency in't, for now I have learn'd to be a Gentlewoman, I'll do as the Gentle Volk do, I'll not have another Husband dangling at my Tail, like our Roger, that I could ne'er ſpend a Shilling at a Wake or a Goſſipping, but I muſt be call'd to an Account for't; but methinks he hangs off mainly.

sp.speaker: Peeper.
sp.p: Shall I tell you, he is reckon'd the Handſomeſt Man in Town, all the Ladies are in Love with him; if you don't mind your Hits, you'll loſe him. The only way for a Widow to ſecure a Young Gentleman, is to let him into her Eſtate; now Madam, did he once ſee the Writings I have ſeen, I'd engage him yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: But I dan't know if it be ſafe or no, for I remember Roger wou'd never let me zee 'em in all his Life, but now he's Dead—why what care I who zee'n; I'll carry him to my Trunk and ſhew him all—

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh Madam, do it decently, I'll fetch out your Trunk, and you ſhall pretend to be looking over ſome Mortgage, and ask his Advice in't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Wench, that will do, vetch 'em— [Exit Peeper.]
Well, I long till I am Dizned zo I do—come, come.
Zetten down, and let me put on my vine Rigging Wench, Hark! zombody Knocks—

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Odſo Mr. Belvil's here—he's come ſooner than he promis'd, which ſhews the greater Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy,
sp.p: A murrain take theſe People, they ſtaid Chattering ſo long, or I might have been Dreſs'd now; hold away. [Runs to the Trunk and takes up the Papers.]

sp.speaker: Peeper.
sp.p: I have kept my Word, Sir, there are the Papers diſplay'd. [Aſide to Belvil.]

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Honeſt Peeper—now to keep my Word with this Old Gentleman, who has once more reconcil'd me to his Neice—Ha! Widow, how doſt thou do Widow?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Do you underſtand Law Captain?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: No Faith, the Sword's my Profeſſion, yet there are ſome Caſes I underſtand; pray what is yours, Widow?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Louk ye, I can't Read theſe Lawyers Crampt Hand de zee, and I'd pray you look 'em over a little, they may be your own another day.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: A long day firſt, if thou—art an Incumbent upon it—with all my Heart; this Induſtrious Wench has wrought her to my purpoſe. [Aſide.] Sits down.]
Let me ſee. [Reads.] An Account of the Eſtate of um, um—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Did not I do it right now?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh, Excellent, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let me alone for Trivance, and ſiche—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: A Deed of Truſt for James Beaumont Eſquire. Ha, the very Writing Sir Thomas mention'd—this muſt along with me— [Puts it up.] Why, you are a Fortune for a Lord, Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Nay, nay, dan't Joak—I have ſomething to truſt to you zee Captain; you ſhall have warm Winter Quarters Captain; Ho, ho—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Widow, I'll Kiſs thee for that I'faith.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Pſhaw, zee now how you all white a Body, but your Breath is zo zweet—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I wiſh I cou'd ſay the ſame by yours. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Od in my mind a ſmells like a Noſegay—pray Captain let me ſmell it again.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Withal my Heart. [Kiſſes her again.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: I like him mainly; wou'd it was over once, that I might have'm all to my ſelf— [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Oh, the Monſter grows ſo Loving, that if Robin comes not to my Reſcue, as I order'd him, I ſhall be Smother'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy.
sp.p: Zhour, and zhour, you have Bewitch'd me Captain; I'm all in a trembling Fit, and my Fleſh glows like an Oven zo it does.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh, her Condition is eaſily to be gueſs'd; I have been in ſuch a Twitter my ſelf before now.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, Sir! The General ſtays in his Coach to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My dear Widow I muſt beg your Pardon at this time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy,
sp.p: But when will you come again Captain? they zay 'tis very unlucky to be long a Wooing. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'll ſpeak to the Man in Black this Evening Widow, and then—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy,
sp.p: Ay, Ay, I know what's to be done then as well as e're a Londoner of 'em all. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: to Peeper.] Heark ye I don't think her Rich enough, manage your Affairs with Sir John Sharper, do you hear? But there's thy Fee—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dowdy,
sp.p:
Well I ſhall carry a handzomer Man into Zomerzetſhire than the High-Sheriff of the County: Come
Peeper, come in and let me Dreſs, for zhour if I had had all this vine Gear on, a wou'd ha Married me now.—

sp.speaker: Peeper,
sp.p: As much as ever—

head.hi: SCENE the outſide of Lucinda's Houſe.

div.stage: Enter Iſabella Dreſt like a Country-Maid with Toylet.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: A tite Country Laſs, hang me Madam if I ſhou'd know you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I wou'd not have you, I ought to be diſguis'd for my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: But Madam do you think Lucinda does not know her Tenant's Daughter that is coming up to London, which you are to Perſonate?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: No, no, She never ſaw her; her Taylor has inform'd me of every Circumſtance; him I have brib'd to my Intereſt; here he comes, get you gon, you have Belvill's Key, be ready for all my Orders; Act as I directed, and preſerve your Acquaintance with Robin.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Fear me not—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Well Mr. Shread, do you think you can manage this Affair?

sp.speaker: Shread,
sp.p: Manage it Madam! What is it I can't do for this Purſe? Why Madam I can work Miracles! I can ſteal as much out of a Pair of Breeches as will make a Coat; and for telling a Lye with an honeſt Face, let little Shread alone.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I have been ſo much with my Couſin Dowdy ſince She came to Town, I warrant I hit the Country Dialect—Come, Knock at the Door. [He knocks.]

sp.speaker: Shread,
sp.p: Sir pray let your Lady know here's a young Country-Maid, Farmer Rent-Land's Daughter, come to wait on her.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Come in and I'le acquaint my Lady—

div.stage: Re-enter Iſabella and Shread as into the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: She's coming, and Belvill's here, I ſee his Footman; now if I'm but receiv'd I ſhall be a Spy upon their Actions, watch all their Turns, and break their Meaſures.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How de do Mr. Shread—is this the Daughter of Farmer Rentland, that he writ to me about?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Yes and pleaſe you forſooth Madam, and I have another Letter from Vather in my Pouch— [Looking for a Letter.]

sp.speaker: Shread,
sp.p: Madam the Girl is a little Clowniſh, her Father's my Couſin, he writ to me to meet her at the Carriers and bring her to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Very well, your Father's an honeſt Man, he deſires me to let you be in my Houſe till he comes up to Town in order to put you to the Change—you are welcome—She is very pretty. Sweet-heart don't you wonder at this fine City?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I kno'nt how vine 'tis yet, for one can zee nought for Crowd, I ſuppoſe 'tis Vair Time, there's zuch—thruſting and ſqueezing.

sp.speaker: Shread,
sp.p: She appears Rough to your Ladyſhip, but the Girl has good natural Parts and apt to learn—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I like her Plainneſs, leave her with me, I'll take great Care of her.

sp.speaker: Shread,
sp.p: Yes, Madam; good bye Couſin.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Good bye—you'l bring my Bundle and my Box—beſure you wait without for my farther Orders.

sp.speaker: Shread.
sp.p: I will—your Servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's your Name fair Maid?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Dorothy and pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And do you think you ſhall be contented to ſtay with me till your Father comes to Town Mrs. Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Contented forſooth! od zhour, and zhour, I ne'er ſaw nought zo Handſome in all the Days of my Breath. Zhour I cou'd look at you all Day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Does the Country teach Flattery too?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Madam, where are you? we ſhall be too late for the Show.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Zhow! Oh dear forſooth take me with you to zee the Zhow—How my Heart beats. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What pretty Country Girl is this?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: One of my Tenant's Daughters; we'll take her with us to your Lodging.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: To his Lodgings, mum—now a diſpatch to Toylet. I'll fit you there. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: With all my Heart, there's Innocence and Beauty in her Face; if you pleaſe to get ready, Madam, I have only two Words to diſpatch with your Uncle and I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Here he comes Sir—we'll leave you; Come Mrs. Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Yes forſooth—

l.hi: Thus conceal'd, if none my Plot diſcover,
This Country Girl may Cheat you of your Lover.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, Sir Thomas, what wou'd you Reward the Man with that ſhou'd bring you the Writings you deſir'd? ha Friend?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say •• thou my Boy! I wou'd give him, let me ſee what wou'd I give him—I wou'd give him as much as I have given to the Lawyers to no purpoſe, which is full Fifteen Hundred Pounds. But haſt thou got 'em my Hero?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Fifteen Hundred Pound, piſh; will you give me your Niece?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Fy, fy, fy, a Wife! Why the Devil ſhou'd a young Fellow's Head run of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Becauſe a young Fellow is very much in Love.

sp.speaker: Sir. Tho.
sp.p: Why Love her Boy, I wou'd have thee Love her, but prithee talk no more of Marriage—but let me ſee the Writings.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Love her! Why what does he mean—he wou'd not have me lie with her ſure—See 'em, why here they are—but I muſt know what right you have to theſe Papers Sir. Thomas e'er I part with them, for I wou'd not be guilty of a baſe Action; beſides the Widow and the whole Eſtate is at my Service—I can Marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I had rather ſee thee Hang'd—I'll give you my Honour that nothing ſhall redound to your Diſgrace in this Affair. Surely you may take my Word young Man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It never ſhall be ſcrupled by me; there, take 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir. Tho.
sp.p: Moſt Joyfully: Ay, theſe are they, let me Embrace thee my Boy for this good Service—But heark ye, don't you Marry that ill-manner'd Jug, the Relict of a cheating old Rogue, that has not left a Foot of Eſtate but what he deſerv'd to be Hang'd for.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In my Conſcience this old Fellow wou'd have me Marry no Body; what a Devil does he pretend to? Egad I wiſh he does not lay claim to me for his Son at laſt.
Ha! Sir Charles, what ſay'ſt thou, wou'd not Matrimony agree with thee, if thou lik'd the Woman?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Or with any Man certainly.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why don't you Marry then Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Becauſe I can't have the Woman I like Sir Thomas, and ſhe that I'm deſtin'd for, neither likes me, nor I her, and to ſhew the true Nature of a Wife before ſhe wears the Title, ſhe's gone to the Bath this Morning without taking Leave.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Nay, if ſhe has ſuch an early Inclination to the Bath, thank thy Stars thou art not Marry'd Boy, for the Bath is a Pregnant Place; I know a Virgin that went there to be cur'd of the Green-ſickneſs, and came back with a Timpany, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why hark ye, Sir Charles, how will you keep your Word then, no Pretentions to Lucinda, ſince you can't produce your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How's that, how's that, haſt thou a Mind to my Neice, Knight, ſhe's a witty Baggage, I tell you that, and a weighty one too, twenty Thouſand Pound beſide my Bleſſing, court her, win her, and wear her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Devil, what becauſe he has a Title?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And a good Eſtate Belvill, put in that.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sink the Eſtate, the Brave deſpiſe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Yet the Bold fight for't.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, 'tis for Honour we hazard Life, and Eaſe, to preſerve ungrateful Men like you, in what do's he merit Lucinda more than I—nor ſhall he dare think of her while I wear this. [Lays his Hand on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Hownot dare! ſuch Language, Sir, I ſhall not take, tho' from a Friend.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nor a Friend ſhan't take a Miſtreſs from me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Mettled Lads i'faith—A Miſtreſs Sir, pray what Hopes have you had relating to that Affair?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hopes Sir, did not you give me Leave to love her?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: But as I take it, that was not Leave to marry her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Did you not take Pains to reconcile us to Day?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: True, becauſe I thought her in the Wrong.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And have you not promis'd ſhe ſhall come to my Lodgings to ſee the Embaſſadour go by? Do you make any Scruple of letting her be ſeen in my Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: No, for I don't think thee Scandalous, and ſhe ſhall come to thy Lodgings, and I'll come with her; yet this is nothing to the Purpoſe—Thou art a pretty Fellow faith—but a Little too impudent to expect Twenty Thouſand Pound, with nothing but a red Coat and a Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is this your Probity, I ſhall begin to ſuſpect every Thing, I find why you extorted the Promiſe from me, never to marry her without your Conſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You ſhall have no Cauſe to blame me, I am, and will be thy Friend—Sir Charles you are out of Humour, never mind the young Warriour, by Mars the God of War, thou haſt my Conſent, addreſs her Man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So has all the Creation, I think—What a Pox does this old Fellow aim at!—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I am not to be deter'd by his Threats; but 'tis Lucinda muſt decide this.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, even if ſhe conſent, you ſhall diſpute the Prize with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Let it come to that, ye Fates, and ſee how gladly I wou'd meet thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If you are ſo hot, let us diſpatch it now. [Lays his Hand to's Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: With all my Heart—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I'll have no Fighting this Day, to Morrow as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well then, to Day we have done.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I am always to be found; Farewel—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come put off your ill Humour, and let's go ſee the Show Boy—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Egad this is a ſtrange unaccountable old Gentleman.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Dowdy dreſt extravagantly in French Night-Cloaths and Furbelows, with Peeper.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: LA yee now, la yee now, ſtand away from the Glaſs, will you, loke, loke, I ſhall ne'er adon ſtaring at my zelf, I'm zhour I'm viner than any of our Volk in Taunton; good Sirs, if old Roger Dowdy were alive, and zeen me thiſen, he wou'd zwear I was going to fly away.

sp.speaker: Peep.
