sp.p: Ah Madam, he underſtood no better—I think you look as well as any Lady at Court.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Nea, nea, I always thought I ſhould look like other Volk an I was but Clad as vinely, and zo I us'd to tell Roger, well, and do I zeem zo vitty Peeper, don't thik Band-Box thruſt out ones Tail rarely? Od one might carry a Griſt to Mill on't, as well as on a Packſadde, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: You are exact from Head to Foot.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p:
Ay, an't I mun, zee my Shoes; [pulls up her Coat a little.] but theſe zilken Hoſe are woundy Cold; han't I got too many Beauty Spots on, in my Mind now my Vace louks juſt like a Plumb-Cake var all the World—
Zhour I ſhall ne'er like thik Head-Gear, one muſt always louk vore-right, vor the Duce a Bit one can zee of either Zide—Faugh, I hate this red Stuff upon my Lips, I can't vorbear liking 'em, and it may be Poiſon for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Good Morrow to your Ladyſhip, bleſs me, ſure I'm miſtaken 'tis not the ſame!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: The very zame Mrs. Brazen, but am I zo chang'd indeed now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Chang'd, why you are a Cherubim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: 'Parel Sheaps you know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Why you'll kill Sir John, at firſt Sight, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Oh dear, I hope not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: He waits without poor Gentleman, but little knows the Danger he is in—Shall I admit him Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Why realy now Mrs. Brazen, I am zorry the Perſon of Quality ſhou'd loſe his Labour, but I can't help it—He ſhou'd ha com'd zooner, de yee zee vor I'm engag'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: How Madam, you han't ſerv'd me ſo I hope?—Make a Fool of a Gentleman of his Fortune, that keeps his Coach, and four Footmen, beſides a Valet-de-Chambre, it's a Shame—He cou'd have made you a Lady Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: His own Coach, and a Lady, zay yee; nay, nay, don't be in a Paſſion—Od I ſhou'd like a Coach, and Ladiſhip hugely—Shall I zee him Peeper?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: By all means ſee him Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Ay but won't the Captain think me valſe hearted then?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Falſe hearted, Madam! Why Ladies here are diſtinguiſh'd by the Number of their humble Servants—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: And ſcarce know two Hours before they Marry which to chuſe—There was my Lady Waver, had three Gentlemen fancied her Wedding Cloaths, and then threw Dies which of the three ſhou'd have her—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dow.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, by the Maſs that's very pretty, why let him come in then—But do you realy think the Captain won't break his Heart?

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh, no no, you need not fear that, perhaps He has two or three Miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: My dear Lady I'll fetch him this Minute—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Zay you zo, nay an it be the vaſhon, I'm reſolv'd to have as many Zweet hearts as I can get—Here put up my Ban Box, zet my voretop, and bruſh my Gown and make me vity—

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: So, ſo, you are exact now Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: There's the Lady, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: You need not tell me which is She, ſuch Beauty is remarkable, her Eyes caſt a Luſtre, bright as the Meridian Sun, which dazles all beholders.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Mercy on me, what high Speaking is this?—Zo I ſuppoſe they talk at Court—Oh dear Sir, you Gentlemen are zo voll of your Jears, that we Country Volk dan't know what to zay to you.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What a Shape is there!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: That's my Ban-Box— [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What a Complexion!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: That's my Paint—Vor they zay my Complexion was but, zo, zo,— [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sharp,
sp.p: What Ruby Lips!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear that—I was affraid I had lick'd it all off. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: I ſwear he is a well bread Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: A Courtier every Inch of him.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Oh Mrs. Brazen, if you have brought me to the Sight of all theſe Charms, and ſhe ſhou'd prove inexorable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Goodneſs forbid.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Oh I'm a dead Man Mrs. Brazen—No Compaſſion Madam, for a poor dying Lover—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Speak Comfort to him Madam, he is juſt ready to Swoon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Why, what can I zay Mrs. Brazen—Will the Gentleman drink a little Cherry-Brandy—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Brandy Madam, ads Heart, is that a Cordial for a dying Lover—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Why 'tis my Cordial when I'm not well, Mrs. Brazen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: A Word, a Look, a Smile revives him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Good Sirs, is it poſſible you can be zo zmitten Sir?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: It is the firſt Wound I e'er receiv'd, tho' I have given Thouſands, and met my Enemies in Clouds of Smoak, and Sheets of Fire, and with this good Sword have made my Way—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Ah dan't draw it good Sir—He is a brave Souldier I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: I proteſt Madam, I begin to pitty him—You can never let ſuch a great Man die.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Ay but then the Captain will die, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Do Madam, let's go into your Cloſet, and taſt ſome of your Cherry-Brandy; oh dear, oh dear—I am very Faint, take her by the Hand, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Indeed I can't, for to tell you the Truth, I am promis'd—

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Promis'd—I'll hunt the World but I will find my Rival out, rip up his Breaſt, and upon my Sword's Point ſend you the Heart you doat on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Oh hold you, hold you, good Sir John—What zhall I do to prevent Murder?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Give him your Hand, and take him into your Cloſet, I ſay, there we'll appeaſe him I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Well, well, come into the Cloſet then; mercy on me, I was never zo lov'd before zhour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Now for my Thouſand Pound—

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Pretty well for the firſt Time; now to try how Generous he'll be to me—If you don't disburſe Sir John, for all your Go between, I'll ſooner match my Miſtreſs to your Valet, I promiſe you that.

div.stage: Enter Belvill, Sir Thomas, Lucinda, Iſabella and Robin.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, and what haſt thou got to treat us Boy? ha!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You ſhall have what you will Sir Thomas, this Lady ſhall name.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Uncle you retain the old Country Cuſtom, all for Eating and Drinking; I am for the Show.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: But what ſays my little Somerſetſbire Laſs, I warrant a Cheeſecake wou'd go down with you now.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: No I thank you Zir, my Belly's full evads, my thinks this is a huge vine Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And in Troth thou art huge Pretty, are all the Farmers Daughters in Somerſetſhire thus Handſome?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Yes indeed, and Handſomer too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Neice I'll gather your Rents next Year in that Country my ſelf—I will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So Mrs. Dorothy, I think you have made a Conqueſt here.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I don't know what you mean Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'faith this is a pretey Rogue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But this Room do's not look upon the Pall-Mall.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No Madam, but the next does; open the Door Robin.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: [aſide to him.] I never ſaw the Key ſince the ſtrange Women were here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What, Whiſpering again!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You careleſs Raſcal, here take my Key.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: The Devil, the Devil—
sp.stage: [Robin goes to open the Door, flies back, and cries out.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Inhuman Monſter, muſt I be expos'd—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Expos'd, 'tis I am expos'd; Confuſion, another Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How, how's this Belvill—What, forgot to let your Miſtreſs out this Morning? ha!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Miſtreſs, 'sdeath, Hell and Furies—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do not counterfeit Surpriſe, this is a palpable Abuſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why truly Neice it do's appear a Sort of an Abuſe as a Man may ſay; but let's hear what Defence he can make—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Defence—I hope it needs none; what End cou'd I have in this—I'm ſure it looks more like a Trick upon me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What mean you Sir, do you ſuſpect I'd give my ſelf the Trouble to put a Trick upon you—Oh Audacious!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold, hold, no hard Words before we know for what.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: [Going up to Toylet.] Get you off, get you off.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nay, nay, egad I'll ſee whether you be Fleſh and Blood, Spirit, or the Devil. [Stops her.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Ah, if this Fool perſiſts we are diſcover'd—I muſt ſhew him my Face—You know not what you do, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I, and how came I hither?

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p:
I long'd to ſee you, and that I might charm you the more, I dreſt my ſelf in my Miſtreſſes Cloaths, and
came in hopes to meet you alone, being caught, I was forc'd to ſay any thing, let me go, or we ſhall never meet again.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Get you gone, if my Maſter finds it out, my Bones will pay for it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Abſurdity! It has indeed a Face of Truth to have People haunt your Lodgings that you know nothing of.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Nay, now I zee 'tis true what we Country Volk zay, that the London Men are all as valſe as the Devil.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What gone again—Raſcal, which Way went ſhe? Why did not you ſtop the Fiend, for 'twas a Fiend I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: If you think ſo Sir, why ſhould you be Angry? For who cou'd ſtop the Devil.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'll make you fetch the Devil Sirrah if ſhe be gone. [Looking about.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I'll try Sir. [Going.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Nay, nay, that's ſending the Devil after his Dam, as we zay in Zomerſetſhire, my poor Judgement tells me, he's no vit Perſon to zend after her zhour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Right, his Man doubtleſs is in the Secret—Even this Innocent cau find out your Deceit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Deceit, ſtay here Dog.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Madam ſend who you pleaſe—'sdeath. [Stamps, and ſeems to perſwade Luc.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Let me go forſooth, I'm zhour I know her Gown agen—I minded her when ſhe ſliv'd off.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let little Roſie Cheek go—Why what a Buſle is here about a Gipſie—But thoul't not find the Way back my Girl.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Oh never vear me, I've an Engliſh Tongue in my Head—I've vound the Way over Heaths, Copſes, and Commons you'd be maz'd in.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your Words are vain, back to the Nations you have been bred in, where Women are ſo coming to your Wiſhes, there needs no Truth nor Conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Truth—I think Truth's my Foe, for I never made ſo much uſe of her to ſo little Purpoſe in my Life, I believe you wiſh'd a Quarrel, and wanted only Opportunity, elſe what I've ſaid wou'd have convinc'd you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Believe ſo ſtill, and ſee my Face no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why Neice, Neice, won't you ſtay for little Somerſetſbire—She's gone—Look ye now, did not I tell you Matrimony wou'd not agree with you, yet you wou'd Marry I warrant—Take my Word for't, you are not made for one another.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I wiſh we had never ſeen one another. [Walking about diſordered.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I ha vound her ifaith.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, and who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: A very vine Lady I aſure you that, but where's Miſtreſs? var I ſhan't tell you what zhe zaid to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Oh ſhe's gone ſtark Mad Child—Prethee tell as Reaſonable Folks—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Said, why did'ſt thou ſpeak to her?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Yes marry did I, and ſhe got into a huge vine Coach, zo zhe did, and call'd me into her, and pull'd off her Vizard, and zhow'd me the vineſt Vace that ever I zaw, zhour, and zhour 'twas as bright as the Zun, ſhe zaid ſhe was in Love with you to diſtraction mun, and vow'd ſhe wou'd have you whatzomever it coſt her.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What a confounded Lye has this Country Toad told? And egad I dare not contradict her. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why hark ye Belvill, don't your Chops water at this Story, ha? My Hero! adod thou wert wrapt up in thy Mother's—Faith thou wert, thou wert I faith Boy—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Piſhaw, ſhe does not know a Woman of Condition from an Orange Wench—Some tawdry Drab in a Hackney-Coach.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: He makes very bold with my Miſtreſs truly. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Nay this was no Stage Coach I'm Zhour, it was as rich and as full of Toſſels, as Squire Penſilly's laſt Exeter Zize.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What not warm yet? Why it may be a Dutcheſs for ought you know—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Devil—Sir Thomas, either reconcile me once more to your Niece, or by Jove I'll diſcover the Grand Secret, and ſet the Widow upon your Back.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Here's a Dog now, in my Conſcience, I believe you'd make a good States Man—Sirrah, what the Action you do in the Morning, will you be ſuch a Rogue to Peach in the Afternoon?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I'm out at all this—Sure he was born without Curioſity—Or is grown Conſtant to torment me. [Aſide.
But Sir, zhan't we go home to my Lady? Mahap Zhee may be Zick She's vext zo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And pretty Creature won't you ſpeak for me?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: No by my Troth ſha'n't I, I believe you are valſe, zo I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come along Dolly. [Takes her by the Arm.] Ah ſuch an Eye, an ſuch a—Come along Dolly—Let me ſee you in the Evening, de you hear Belvill, and if the Lady comes again with Squire Penſilly's Coach, ſtrike her Boy, ſtrike her.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Your Zervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What will be the Event of this?—What Woman cou'd this be?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why do you Snear Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ah Sir, I wou'd tell you, if I durſt—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What is't you wou'd tell me? Out with it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ay, but will you forgive me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If thou canſt explain this Riddle, I will.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why then Sir, all that this Country Wench has told you, is a notorious Lye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Becauſe Sir, the Woman that was here is a Miſtreſs of mine, who lodges at the next Door.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A Miſtreſs of yours Sirrah in that Garb—What was her Buſineſs, and how do you know it?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe ſhew'd me her Face, and told me ſhe came to ſee me, the Cloaths ſhe ſaid were her Ladies, I ſuppoſe ſhe had a Mind to captivate me, 'tis the very Maid to that very Lady that you left in your Lodgings to Day Sir, and ſhe told me too by the by, Sir, that her Miſtreſs is no more marry'd than you are.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: There muſt be ſomething in this more than I can find out—Egad I'll endeavour to ſee her at leaſt—Hark ye Sirrah, fetch me this Woman inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Od ſo, yonder ſhe goes—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: They may talk what they will of Spain, but for my part, I think the Engliſh Women can manage an Intreague with the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Here ſhe is Sir, trembling Ripe, anſwer for your ſelf now.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray tell me Miſtreſs, why is my Lodgings your Randezvous, and what do you deſign by thoſe Appearances?

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Diſſembling Varlet, to betray me to thy Maſter—Look ye Sir, ſince I'm caught, the Truth ſhall out; for my Part I only obey'd the Commands of my Lady, as we Servants muſt you know.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Very good, but prethee who is your Lady Child?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ay there's the Query—

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: It's my Lady Elizabeth Lovemore, a great Heireſs, and very beautiful, but I can't help ſaying I think her a little Mad to run after you, when there's fifty dying for her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Humph!—And is ſhe ſo very Handſome doſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: A reigning Toaſt—admir'd even by her own Sex, and then you muſt allow ſhe's Handſome indeed—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Now I queſtion if it would not puzzle Patridge the Almanack Maker, to find out whether this Wench Lyes or not?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And where do's this beautiful Lady of thine live, ha?

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: In Golden-Square the third Houſe of the Right-Hand.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: There I have trapt you Gentlewoman, don't you Lodge at next Door.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Yes, what then? Can't my Lady Lodge me at any Door that ſhe pleaſes, when 'tis A Propo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This is a whimſical Tale, however I reſolve to ſee the End of it, name your Time when I may ſee this fair Incognita; I'm not obdurate faith, ſhe ſhan't die, aſſure her that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: If ſhe do's he muſt have chang'd his Nature with the Country.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: A Meſſenger in the Evening ſhall bring you to the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'll expect it, 'tis in vain for me to think of Conſtancy, the Devil is ſure to throw ſomething in my Way, to hinder my pious Reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I'm of your Mind Sir, and for my Part I have not found this ſingular Paſſion turn to any Account with me, ſince you begun, therefore Sir, if you'd take my Advice, e'en arm your ſelf with a Bottle of Burgundy, that you may attack your new Miſtreſs with the better Courage.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But Pox I find Lucinda ſtill ſticks here— [Pointing at his Heart.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nothing like a Glaſs to waſh her away Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It ſhall be ſo—
sp.l: I'll Sing, and Drink, and Drown her in Champaign,
Then warm'd with Wine, I'll break the ſlaviſh Chain,
And ſhe ſhall ſue to Conquer me again—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good Heavens, who wou'd wiſh to be a Woman? Nature's unerring Laws are ſtill the ſame as when ſhe form'd the Order of the World—But Cuſtom has debauch'd her Rules, and given Tyrant Men pretence to glory in their Falſhood—What Libertine e'er loſt a Friend for being ſo? Nor ſtands he leſs in Fame for perjur'd Vows, that has betray'd a Thouſand truſting Maids, whilſt we for every trifling Fault condemn'd, become the Subject of licentious Tongues, yet ſure our Crimes are Regiſtred alike in the great Impartial Book above—

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Madam, Sir Charles Richley to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Bring him up— [Exit Foo.] tho' I'm in no Humour to Entertain—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Do I not invade your Privacy Madam? There ſeems a Melancholly ſettled on your Brow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I confeſs Sir Charles I'm under ſome diſorder. [ſighing.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Happy the Man for whom thoſe Sighs are paid, as I am wretched in Deſpair.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Oh Belvill, unworthy of ſuch Love or Beauty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nam'd you not Belvill, Sir? What of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I did—May not a Wretch that's Raving in a Feaver expreſs his eager Wiſhes for the Bowl, which he ſees his healthful Friend paſs by untaſted.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p:
Why ſhou'd I conceal the Burning Pain, when perhaps another Opportunity may never offer—I love
you Madam, not with a looſe ungarded Flame, but all the Faculties of my Soul are center'd in you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How—Wou'd you ſupplant your Friend? Is this like a Man of Honour?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Oh I had died in Silence, had not he, the happy he provok'd me, he threaten'd me like a Boy, he threaten'd me, if I preſum'd to own my Paſſion—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then 'tis me he Loves above the reſt, alas! how apt are we to flatter our Diſeaſe. [Aſide.] And cou'd you hope, that I ſhou'd liſten to an ungrateful Man?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Alas! too much you do—and ſince when next Belvill and I meet—Fate only knows the Conſequence—Let me beg this Favour, tho' I confeſs 'tis boldneſs, to ask if you deſign Belvill for your Husband?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You take indeed a Liberty beyond what I expected from you, but I'll not diſguiſe the Truth, of all Men living, Belvill made the firſt Impreſſion in my Heart, and cou'd he clear himſelf of this late Accident, I think I ſhou'd prefer him.

sp.speaker: Sir. Cha.
sp.p: Now who's ungrateful, he or I? Had I ſuch Hopes, what Crowns Shou'd Bribe me to forſwear the Marriage? [Half aſide.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How's that? Take heed how you traduce him, am I ſo cheap, that he ſhou'd Swear he wou'd not Wed me, Confuſion! 'tis Falſe, and were he here, you durſt not for your Soul affirm it.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Yes, ſince you have hear'd me, if a thouſand Points were levell'd at my Breaſt, I wou'd maintain it, and in the Face of Death proclaim he ſaid, he had Sworn never to Marry you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Sworn, oh Impudence! Oh weakneſs in my ſelf to liſten to an unknown Villain, his Mercenary Soul ne'er harbour'd generous Thoughts: He ſhou'd have been with Gold rewarded for the Buſineſs of his Sword, and the Defence he made againſt Midnight Robbers paid with Money, not a Heart. What did his baſe degenerate Soul
hope I ſhou'd yield to looſe Deſires? And durſt he make his Friend his Confidant? Deſtraction! The bare Idea warms me to Revenge, and turns me all to Fury.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: What have I ſaid? Oh let me Madam, tho' againſt my ſelf atteſt that in all our Converſation from our firſt Aquaintance, I never knew him ſwerve from Honour, what e'er his Reaſons were to Swear it—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Revoke not what thou haſtſaid, but, hence begone, and leave me to my Self, for Tygers, Wolves and Serpents are leſs hurtful than thy barbarous Kind.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Your Commands do's like the Hand of Fate forbid my Stay—But oh! remember 'tis the faithfulleſt of your Slaves Obeys you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: So, Sir Charles is gone—His Exit is my Cue, may his Love ſucceed I ſay—I'll help it as forward as I can—What an Air ſhe gives her Self—The very bare imagination of ſlighted Love is the Devil I find—Oh vorſooth an't you well, will you pleaſen that I ſhall get you zomewhat—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Alas poor Innocence 'tis not in thy Power, to aſſwage the Torment of my Mind—didſt thou e'er meet with an ungrateful Swain?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: No, no they are all true in our Country, I heard of but one valſe, and he had been at London—But you don't ask me about the toping Lady, I vollow'd from the Vine Gentleman's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I had forgot it, didſt thou ſee her—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Did I, yes I did zhour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And what was the Creature?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Nay, he can tell you that vorſooth better than I, for they are mainly well acquainted, I vound that—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha! how didſt thou find it? Did the ugly Thing tell thee?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Nay in troth, ſhe is not ugly vorſooth—tho' I hate her for your Sake—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Faithful, kind, good natur'd Creature.— [Hugs her.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: She gin me this Silver Book, and writ down where ſhe lives, and deſires you of all Love to let her Zee you this Evening, and ſhe'll tell you all, I did not zay one Word to him on't.— [Gives her the Book.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A plain Direction—I thought never to have concern'd my ſelf with this vile Man's Affairs, but I'll detect him throughly—then throw him from my Heart for ever—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I hope ſo e'er I have done. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How bleſt, how happy is this Rural Maid?
All Cares are baniſh'd from thy peaceful Breaſt:
Thou never wert to luckleſs Love betray'd,
Unknowing of the Racks that break my Reſt.
Thou ne'er the Flattering Wiles of Men believ'd,
Deceiving none, thou art by none deceiv'd.

head.hi: SCENE Changes to Mrs. Dowdy's Lodgings.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Dowdy, Sharper, Mrs. Brazen, Peeper, and Equipage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Well, I proteſt you are a waggiſh Man, Lord how you have rouzl'd and touzl'd one?—All my Rigging hangs as if 'twas zhaked on with a Zhed Vork, as the old Zaying is—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Ay there's a Man for you now Widow, ah wou'd I were in your Place, a brisk young Dog I Faith, I ask your Pardon, Sir, John, I'm a little Free—But 'tis my Way and Madam's Cherry Brandy was ſo good—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Will you have t'other Cup, Mrs. Brazen? Ads lid my Hearts Open.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Nay then take a Souldier in that will defend the Breach Widow. [Embracing her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Zhaw you ſpoil all ones Rump, you zqueeſe one zo—In troth I think him main handſom— [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Matters go rarely, if no Devil croſs it, I ſhall come in for my Wages at laſt. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bell.

l.hi: If a Nymph proves peeviſh and Coy,
Turn off thy Glaſs, never mind her:

sp.l: Take Bacchus in Room of the Boy,

l.hi: Drink till the Goddeſs grow kinder.

sp.p: How ſtands Taunton Dean now Widow? Ha! [Hickups.] what's here a Rival?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! this fighting Fellow here, we are all unravell'd I doubt?— [Aſide to Mrs. Brazen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: I fear ſo too—I hate this Spark, he has too much Sence for me to get any Thing by him. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Let me ſee who are you? [Hickups.] What do you pretend to, ha? Hold up your Head, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Oh dear Sir, what do you do, you'll ſpoil all, did not you ſay— [To Belvill.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Look ye [Hickups.] I don't care what I ſaid, I'll take Care of the Widow.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ah dear Belvill don't prevent my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Don't tell me of your Fortune, was not you kickt this Morning? [Hickups.] Anſwer me that.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: So, if my Contrivance ruins all now, I ſhan't come in for a Souce. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: A duce take you for bringing your drunken Maſter here, when we were upon the Point of Concluding. [to Rob.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me do with him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Widow, why Widow I tell you [Hickups] this Scoundrel ſhan't have you Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Stand away Mrs. Brazen, look yee Sir, Matters are gone varder than you think vor, and don't zhow none of your drunken Frolicks here, de yee zee, for I value them not a Ruſh—What zhour I ne'er broke Gold with yee—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No matter for that, I'll ſhew you your Bargain Widow, and then I have done—He is—

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: A Plague of ill Luck.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: He is Widow— [Hickups.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: What is he, uds lid dan't you affront any civil Gentleman in my Houſe, I dan't love yee well enough de yee zee to bear that; what is he now, what is he, he is a Man I hope.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Sweet Captain. [Softly.
'Sdeath Sir, what do ye mean? [To Bel. in a loud Voice.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Don't exalt your Voice Sirrah; [Hickups] don't I know you for a very Poltron, noted for your Cowardice, and kick'd out of all Converſation for your Lying—So Widow, I have warm'd ye—Now Robin I'll go Home and ſleep till the Hour of Aſſignation—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: A Rival's Rage, ſtark Mad, he has loſt you Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Come how de yee, Sir John, od my Heart goes apit apat, I was woundy afraid yee wou'd have fit.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: No, no, he knew your Preſence hindred me from drawing, elſe I'd ha made a Cartridge of his Skin, and pounded his Fleſh into Gun-Powder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: A dod he has a World of Courage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: Ah Madam, you'd ſay ſo, if you had ſeen what I have ſeen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Od I am glad I'ſcap'd this drunken Rogue, but hold yee, hold yee, he can't ha no Claw upon my Eſtate, can ha, 'cauſe I ha kept him Company?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: He—Marry Sir John, Madam, I'll ingage ye ſecure.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Come Madam, ſpeak a kind Word, my Coach waits at the Door, let's go take the Air.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braz.
sp.p: And a Glaſs of good Canary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Of all Liquours indeed Zack Wine pleaſes me beſt. For the Air, de yee Zee that's but little, it all zmells of Zea-Coal.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: So, there's Hopes agen.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Do, Madam go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: I don't know how to deny them, they are ſuch courteous Volk.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: Mrs. Brazen, before the Marriage is over, you muſt ſecure me my Hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: I will, I will.
sp.l: Thus by our Art are Women bought and Sold,
They run the Hazard, but we ſhare the Gold—

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.stage: Enter Iſabella in a rich Night-Dreſs, with Toylet.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: WELL, my Wit will let me no farther into this Deſign, when you have brought 'em hither, do you imagine it poſſible to deceive 'em any longer, Madam?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p:
If I pleaſe it is—But my Plot draws towards an End—If when I diſcover my ſelf, he ſhou'd ſtill retain his Love for her—I have reap'd this Advantage however by it, I ſhall get rid of that odious Contract, for I can prove that Sir Charles made violent Love to Lucinda, and will
force him to releaſe me, on that pretence I'll fix the Reaſon of my Frolick, if Belvill's falſe, but never think of Love again.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: I wiſh the Pains you have taken to get free from one, and try the Conſtancy of the other, do's not caſt a Reproach upon your Fame.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: That I weigh'd before, the Cenſure of the World is guided by Prejudice, or Partiality, and not worth my Care, I depend on none, and can juſtify my Conduct to my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: I'm glad on't with all my Heart, I fancy you'll have a Tryal of Patience, for I dare ſwear Belvill and Lucinda are reconcil'd again, they will find you out Madam in your Roguery.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: If they be, I fancy I ſhall break the Peace once more, and make the Breach yet wider; is every Thing in order, have you told my Footmen what Name I wear at preſent.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and they have put on all their ſtrange Liveries, and ſtare, and ask a thouſand Queſtions, but I ſeal'd their Mouths with your Ladyſhip's Gratuity.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Very well, be ready to admit her, for I know ſhe'll inſtantly be here, I left her upon the Teaze.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Bleſs me Madam, ſhe's coming.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Now for my Tragical Face. [Runs and ſits down on the Couch.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She appears indeed no common Beauty. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I doubt not, Madam, your Surpriſe at my Deſire to ſee you here, but when you ſhall know the Ties I have to that falſe Man, ungrateful Belvill, I'm ſure you will forgive me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p:
Our Sex are too apt to credit the Appearances of Truth from the proteſting Tyrants—I have Reaſons to ſuſpect
Belvil baſe, and long to know your Story—Sure my Eyes deceive me, or ſhe reſembles much the Country Maid I have at Home—But 'tis impoſſible; Betty take the Coach, and fetch Dorothy hither. [Aſide to Betty.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ask your Pardon—Some Orders to my Maid, and now I'm all Attention.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Humph, I gueſs thoſe Orders, but no matter. [Aſide.] Madam I was born many Leagues from hence in Flanders, my Name is Donna Clara; 'twas my hard Fate to ſee this Captain Belvill, there he Conquer'd me, as few I think can make Reſiſtance to his Charms, I Marry'd him, gave him my Heart and Fortune, the laſt was I'm ſure too great to be deſpis'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Marry'd, oh the harden'd Villain!

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Nay, and what ſhou'd have endear'd him more to me, my Wedlock Joys were bleſt with a lovely Boy, his perfect Image, in his Parents Time become an Orphan.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh the deteſted Monſter! What a Precipice have I eſcap'd—Go on thou injur'd Fair, and be aſſur'd I will aſſiſt thee.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: He ſaid his Buſineſs call'd him to this Country, and left me with the firm Promiſe of his endleſs Faith—I writ, and writ, but ſtill no Anſwer came; at length, directed by my Headſtrong Love, I follow'd him, but oh how Cold was my Reception! He forthwith charg'd me I ſhou'd change my Name, and as I priz'd my Life, not to declare my Marriage—I obey'd in all, nay even ſupply'd him to my own undoing, but being inquiſitive to find the fatal Cauſe of this ſad Alteration, I learnt 'twas you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh how I hate my ſelf for having been the Innocent Author of ſuch Wrongs.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Twas I caus'd that diſturbance in his Lodgings, nor durſt I ſhew my Face, dreading his Rage, I have no Friend in England and am moſt Forlorne— [Weeps.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Methinks there's Sympathy in Woes like theſe which melt me into Pitty—Which Way can I retrieve me in your loſt Opinion, or how redreſs your anxious Sorrows?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: He ſent Word he'd inſtantly be here, tell him the Ills he has committed, but reproach him gently.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Be ſure I'll tell him.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And doubtleſs he'll deny it with Imprecations, but I'll be near to Second you.
The Devil's in him now if he don't long to ſee the Woman has made all theſe Stories on him— [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Madam, my Maſter—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The perfidious Traytor ſhocks me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: A Trembling ſeizes me all o'er permit me to retire till you have taxt him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do, and compoſe your Self.

div.stage: Enter a Footman ſhewing Belvill in.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, where's this Loving Lady of yours?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ay too loving for you baſe Man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha Lucinda—Trapt agen—now ſparkling Champain aſſiſt me—why this is kindly done—and yet faith 'tis not fair neither, why did not you ſend your own Name, I did but Gallop now, I ſhou'd have flown then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh unparrallel'd Confidence, how cam'ſt thou by that honeſt looking form, haſt thou not a Cloven Foot?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Humph ha! egad I think not. [Looking on his Feet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Stand off thou vile Contagion, bear to thy Injur'd Wife thy boaſted Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Wife!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She well deſerves what ever thou can'ſt pay.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Devil ſhe do's.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nor can thy Future Life attone the Wrongs thou haſt done her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Done her, who a Pox is ſhe—Wife—Death, what do you mean Madam?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Peeping.] Ay he may well ask that Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh Aſſurance! You don't know Donna Clara, whom you eſpous'd in Flanders?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Donna Clara, Donna Fury, Madam, this is too much.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Too much indeed thou ſteel'd Impoſture, could'ſt thou abandon ſo much Beauty in her blooming Pride, even when Nature to augment thy Joys had bleſt thee with a Son.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Death, Madam, you make me Mad, a Son! it may be ſo, tho' hang me if I know any thing of the Matter.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nor you don't know that you're in her Houſe I ſuppoſe neither?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Not I faith—I don't know whoſe Houſe it is, nor do I care three Farthings; go on with your Banter—Donna Clara—A Son, Wife, and the Devil.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come forth Madam, and confront this Traytor. Now, Sir, do you ſtart?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha! whoſe this—What do's ſhe intend?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: [Kneels.] Forgive me, Sir, that I have reveal'd the Secret, but my impatient Love no longer cou'd endure a Rival.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Secret, what do's ſhe mean? Egad ſhe's very handſome, pray Madam, who are you, Donna Clara, or the Lady Elizabeth Lovemore?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Oh wretched! am I then forgotten?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sink me if I Remember you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh that my Uncle now were here, that I at once might blaſt his Hopes, and baniſh him our Houſe for ever—Riſe Madam, he is not worth your tender Care—Do's not thy Soul reflect upon thy Actions, and ſhew thy Guilt as black as Hell?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Damnation, Madam what deſign ye by theſe Pretences? [Walks about in a Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What did you deſign baſe Man in your Addreſs to me?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Twas your Beauty, Madam, made him Falſe; Oh do not chide Him, cruel as he is I love him ſtill.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Gad I'll have ſome Revenge for her Plot. [Aſide. Do'ſt thou ſo my dear pretty Creature, well thy Vertue has overcome me, here where are my [Hugging her.] Servants, let the Bed be made this Minute, I'm impatient till I have thee in my Arms, Madam, you'll fling the Stocking? I'll fancy it is again my Wedding Night, and my beautious Wife not yet enjoy'd. [Kiſſing and embracing her all the while.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh! you know her now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Heavens! what ſhall I do now, what have I drawn upon my Self here?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And how do's my Charming Boy, is he with you?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir, I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ſhe Stammers and bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By all my Joys thou art more charming than when I firſt embrac'd thee, thy Breath is Jeſſamine, thy Boſome ſweeter than Beds of Roſes. [Embracing her:

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: For Honour's ſake ſtand off, hear me and I'll confeſs the Truth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Oh Madam! Dorothy's gone, the Servants tell me ſhe call'd for a Coach in another Air, and away ſhe flung like Lightning—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: More Riddles.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But here's your Uncle and Sir Charles.

div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas, and Sir Charles.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Ha, Sir Charles, I ſhall be expos'd—but muſt reſolve to bear it out. [Turns away.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh Uncle, I am glad you are come to prove the Baſeneſs of your Favourite.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How, how, my Boy baſe?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He's Marry'd, yet impudently deny'd it to her Face; ſhe follow'd him from Flanders, there ſhe ſtands, and I believe you'll think ſhe meritted kinder Uſage.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Then Madam he is not ſo culpable as you imagin'd, he had reaſon for his Oath.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And haſt thou ſhot the Gulf of Matrimony my Lad ha?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So it ſeems, Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why let me ſee thy Wife then—What de ye turn your Back? You need not be aſham'd of my Boy, my Hero Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: How, Iſabella! [Turns her about.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Yes Iſabella, I hope you have no Pretentions to Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Piſhaw, you miſtake Man, this is Donna Clara.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Who the Devil's Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'm ſurpris'd; pray explain this to me, for only I am in the Dark.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why did notyou ſay 'twas his Wife?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I thought ſo—

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: He do's not, or he will not know me— [Aſide] I own I have gone beyond my Sex and Quality, but it was to purchaſe Liberty, and break a forc'd Contract with that perfidious Man who paid his Vows to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I ſhou'd not have put you to this Trouble Madam, if you had let me known your Mind ſooner.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What, am I then a Property, am I a Perſon fit to be Abus'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why then thou art not Marry'd, Man—Have Patience Neice.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I can have none, and will renounce Mankind.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Faith and Troth but thou ſhalt not.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What Devil has poſſeſt thee with ſuch Indifference for a Woman ſo charming, Sir Charles, had not Lucinda engroſs'd my Heart, I cou'd adore this Beauty, and make my only Requeſt, to be what but now ſhe call'd me, Husband.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Some kind Angel inform him who I am, and ſave my Bluſhes. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: She never thought me worth her Conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Nor ever will—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Short and Pithy—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now Madam, I hope my Innocence is clear'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am convinc'd—I ſuppoſe Madam you were my Farmer's Daughter too—

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I was indeed Madam, at your Service—Toylet, and this was the Lady in your Lodgings; when we were there, I keep my Word with you, Sir, you ſee I confeſs all.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now Madam, ſince your Uneaſineſs has diſcover'd your Love, pray let the Parſon make an End of our Platonicks.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: What do I hear? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ſee a real Paſſion cannot be diſguis'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Bleſt Sound. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What! do you know of another Marriage Sir Thomas, ha?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: No, but I know that which you don't know, Boy—Why I'll hold you Fifty Pound you don't know your own Name—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, that's very hard indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: As hard as it is, 'tis true—What's your Name now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: James Belvill, I never had any other Name that I know of.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why look ye there now, did not I tell you, you did not know your Name, then there's the Wrigtings again, you young Dog you, which intitles you to Two Thouſand a Year, and James Beamont Sirrah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How's this, my Name?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: As ſure as he's thy own Brother Girl.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Brother!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Siſter!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What is this he I have ſo often heard you lament? Why did you conceal it from me thus long?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Her Brother, oh lucky Turn! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Becauſe I was reſolv'd he ſhould get the Writings of his Eſtate before he was known, that he might not be plagu'd with Law as I have been.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Then Lucinda's free. Oh Tranſport—Dear Sir Thomas unfold.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Thus then, My Brother was a Merchant, a thriving Man, there were not ſo many Privateers Abroad in his Time, nor the French ſo powerful.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Very well, go on Sir Thomas—I ſhall have a Father at laſt—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: This Daughter, upon his Death-Bed he bequeath'd to me, you his Son he did not think fit to truſt in my Hands, being wheedled by that old Rogue Roger Dowdy his Steward, who inſinuated that I being next Heir, was not proper for your Guardian, ſo prevail'd with my Brother to let him have you, and with you the Writings, Care and Management of the Eſtate—

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Happy Story.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then you are my Uncle, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Certainly Boy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But how are you ſure this is my Brother, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: If you'll give me Leave, dear Madam, you ſhall hear. [Sliely.] Your Father left Effects in Spain, whether Dowdy went to adjuſt 'em, and with him took this proper Fellow, then an Infant; at his Return pretended he was Dead, and produc'd a forg'd Will, wherein he was left my Brother's Heir, in caſe of your Death; but I had private Intelligence from Spain, that he had Boarded you there, and chang'd your Name to Belvill—I have ever ſince been in Law with him till he dy'd: I got him into Chancery which we call the Court of Equity, but 'tis the Court of the Devil, for the old Raſcal brib'd the Lawyers ſo high, that I have hung there theſe Twenty Years.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Oh how my Heart leaps at this Relation. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I ſent for you ſeveral Times, but the Diſtance of Place, and the Man that had the Care of you being a Soldier, you was ſtill remov'd, at laſt I loſt my Intelligence of you in the Spaniſh Netherlands, till that lucky Night that brought you to our Houſe, and being weary of Law, I put you upon that Stratagem to get the Writings.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It agrees with every Circumſtance of my Life; thus let me pay you a Son's Duty for your Care; [Kneels] and now Siſter let me Embrace you with a Brother's Love.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And all my Paſſion ſhall be turn'd to a Siſter's Fondneſs—Whilſt what I as a Lover lik'd, I recommend to fair Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Iſabella, oh that Name rouzes a Thought within my Breaſt, which I cou'd wiſh for ever loſt, ſince the Cauſe is never to be found.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: You do not wiſh to find it I preſume, our Inclinations may poſſibly alter with the Air, we do not breath the ſame in London which we did in Paris.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: You have learnt from the Beau-mond, that the Converſation of a Drawing-Room is beyond that of a Grate.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By Heaven 'tis ſhe, my Iſabella, [Runs and embraces her.] for whom I've ſearcht, and ſigh'd ſo long, now I am bleſt indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What, another turn?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray unriddle this Brother.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You ſhall know it all at large within; let this ſuffice at preſent, this Lady is my Wife by Promiſe, five Years ago in France we plighted Faiths, and nothing now ſhall part us.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You muſt own I have deſerv'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: With this Embrace take my Conſent, [Embrace. ſo thou'lt advance my Intereſt here.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: With all my Soul.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And mine, with all my Spirit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Oh Sir, Mrs. Dowdy, and a whole Coach full of Folks, ſhe has been hunting you all the Town over ſhe ſaid, and ſeeing me at the Door knew you were here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Will you give me leave Madam, to bring 'em into your Houſe? [To Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: With all my Heart, my Time's ſhort in this Houſe, I only hir'd it for this Purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Toy.
sp.p: Oh Robin! your Maſter is found Heir to Two Thouſand a Year.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo, then you and I muſt talk more of the Buſineſs, we ſhall live rarely Girl, for he's generous as a Prince.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Go, bring 'em up.

div.stage: Re-enters with Mrs. Dowdy, Sharper, Brazen, Equipage, and Peeper.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Oh Captain! have I vound you? Z'dslid give me my Writings you ſtole from me, you cheating Knave you, or I'll zet Sir John on your Back.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I am afraid my dear Country Couſin the Right owner has got 'em into his Hands, and won't eaſily return 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sir John—ha, ha, ha, how long has he been a Knight? Why this is Sharper, a Fellow not worth Two Pence if thou art Married to him Widow, much good may do thee—

sp.speaker: S. Ch.
sp.p: The very honourable Gentleman I met this Morning.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Pox on her for bringing me here, wou'd I were well out again. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Well, well, an he be no Knight, I don't care de yezee, he is my Husband, and for all you have chouc'd me out of Two Thouſand Pound a Year, I have enough to maintain him, and make him a Gentleman too, mun.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hark ye, hark ye, take me along with you—Chouc'd you, did you ſay? Have a Care, don't you remember a Child nam'd James Beamont, your Husband carried into Spain, ha?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Od and it troubled his Conſcience mainly zo it did—But what of him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nothing, only I am that Child it ſeems, and have made bold to ſecure my Eſtate, and henceforth will manage it my Self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Zay you zo! nay then 'tis beſt to be quiet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I find Miſtreſs, your Husband was a great Knave—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Zo may your Husband vor ought I know vorſooth—I can't zay much for his Honeſty truly, but I'm zhour I was a good Gentlewoman born, as Cozen Iſbell here can teſtifie.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Don't call me for a Witneſs, for my part I was told I am related to you, but our Acpuaintance began in London.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How, Two Thouſand pound a Year lopt off, wou'd I were unmarried again.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: There's too much for you Raſcal yet—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come Jemmy, you ſhall go in and ſign Releaſes this joyful Day, and forgive her all that's paſt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: But hark ye, hark ye, Sir, [To Sharper.] how muſt I have my Thouſand Pound?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: When you can ſecure the Eſtate you promis'd me, you unconſcionable Jade: Your Judgment, Gentlemen, do's ſhe deſerve a Thouſand Pound for making the Match between us?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'm afraid ſhe rather deſerves to have her Bones broke.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Not a Groat, when the Marriage is over your Buſineſs is done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dow.
sp.p: A Thouſand Pound, oh you graceleſs Puſs—Ad's Life I gin her a Hundred zo I did; let me come at her, I'll pull her Noſe off—

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is good Diverſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Braz.
sp.p: A Hundred Pound! I ſhou'd have a rare Trade on't, if every old Woman was as ſneaking as you in the Matches I have made lately.

sp.speaker: Equi.
sp.p: Don't let your Clack walk here Dol Domiſchief, out, out— [Turns her out.] I ſhall get my Wages. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Peep.
sp.p: 'Tis beſt for me to hold my Tongue, leſt I be ſerv'd the ſame Sauce. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dow.
sp.p: Come Spouſe, let's down into the Country, 'fore George I ha paid woundy Dear for learning London Vaſhons. [Noiſe of Fidles without

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ha, the Fidlers ſmell a Wedding, let's have a Country Dance.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thus for our Good, kind Providence provides,
Unſeen by us through every Labyrinth guides:
'Twas that which kept me from a Siſter's Arms,
And gave me back to Iſabella's Charms.
